story:
Introducing

Hi, my name is Bernard and Im 20 years old. I decided to left my homeland for my dream and went study to Scotland because i think here i will have more opportunities for my dreams.

Right now im in the middle of building my porfolio for apply for university and im reworking on 3d animation project. Unfortunately my old laptop broke down and i have no other facilities for continue at my project and building of my porfolio. I need powerful laptop so i would be able to continue do what I started. I already have all developes done and ready to make it real, i just need tool.

im working part time because i have college three times per week and i need to pay my rent and food. I dont have any bursary or funding from school. I dont have any support from my family so i dont have any chance to earn enough money in time.

 

This is my personal statement for university where I explainied my dreams and plan for my future.

 

Why have I decided to study this course? Because, I need the experience to help me succeed in being successful in a career that I really want to do in my future. I need to know more about what I would like to do and I need explore this part of art in more depth. Im learning in my own time too but I need professional explanations and demonstrations from people who already have the experience I desire.

Why am I so interested in this subject? Because it has always been what I wanted to do.
My mother used to work as designer and through her I learned to see art everywhere around me. I was always surrounded by artists. She was responsible for decoration of whole buildings where as my grandmother used to work for company who designs patterns and designs for textiles.

Art is something that I live in. I’m the kind of person who is always looking for art everywhere. In my case graphic design, packaging, typography, photography are what I'm truly interested in doing and generally I think I have a good sense of balance and harmony in these areas of art and have developed a good sense of what looks right so far although I realise that I have still have much to learn.

I have had a few useful experiences from high school where I was responsible for complete design, layout and cover page of high school magazine. In those four years I started using and learning software like Adobe Photoshop, Illustrator, InDesign and Corel Draw. I have only been to one Photoshop course, after that I taught myself how to use all this software with the aid of watching various tutorials and reading many blogs. People often approach me asking me if I can design posters or various postcards for them because they know that I love to do it and I like a challenge and any chance to prove myself.

My past study was always connected or centered around art, after high school I graduated in art history and decided leave my home country and go to Scotland where I studied Advanced Art and Design at Banff and Buchan College and now currently I'm studying HNC Art and Design, this is now my second year of Art and Design here in Scotland. I think I won’t have any major problems with English language since I was studying this language for more than nine years at school plus two years of real life experience here in Scotland.

Self motivation is one of my strengths and I invest all my free time sketching, drawing, trying to bring my ideas from my imagination alive. Its not easy because I don't have much free time but for the things I love Im always able to find time even at work I will bring my sketch book with me and work on things in my breaks or when its quiet. My hobbies are creatively focused: listening to great music while I'm drawing or designing something on my laptop. I also love reading, mainly fiction and fantasy books and specialized art magazines and blogs such a tumblr.com.

I have been studying English since primary school and then at higher lever in high school. After graduation I decided to try something new and leave my country, so I went to study abroad. I decided to try International Banff and Buchan College. I decided to become independent when I was nineteen, get my own apartment and pay my own bills, get a job. It is not easy but I learnt a lot in a very short time which has taught me a lot about responsibility and the realistic world.

After this course I would like to get a job in a design studio and then after a few years when I have gained some experience I would like to start my own business and start freelance. My plan is start work at home and after that when I will have more clients I would like to rent my own design studio, hire some talented and hard working people to my studio.

story: I want to thank the 3 supports I did get for their contributions to this campaign, and rest assured that I will begin a new, more successful campaign. Your funds will directly aid in this endevour, thank you.

story:
College is a chance to learn about the subjects that will assist you in pursuing your passion.

In agriculture experience is paramount to success.

It only makes sense that a comprehensive agricultural education would combine the best of both worlds.

The University of Nebraska—Lincoln hosts a number of opportunities for students looking to obtain a degree related to agricultural sciences. However, one key, growing portion of agriculture is currently absent from the UNL landscape.

But that’s all about to change

An organic, student-run farm, conveniently located on campus, is in the making.

University of Nebraska students, professors, and Lincoln's Community CROPS have teamed up to transition a former asparagus patch on East Campus into a productive farming plot operating under organic, sustainable practices. This half-acre of land will be a great asset during the growing season.

East Campus Location

However, the growing season is primarily during the summer months--or, in other words, during summer break. Hoop houses, or high tunnels, are incredible tools when it comes season extension. This means we could begin our growing season while students are finishing out spring semester and prepare things for the summer months, when student volunteers may be less available. The season will then continue into the fall semester when students return. With this addition to the farm, we can grow more to serve more and offer more opportunities for students who will be away during the summer to get experience working on the farm.

Hoop House Next to the Field

This will be the first student-run organic farm at UNL. The University has set aside the land for use as an on-campus farm, but it's up to the us to do the rest. Since it's student run, students are responsible for each and every detail related to the farm. This includes everything from finding funding opportunities and abiding by organic regulations, to planting and harvesting, to marketing and record keeping.

Starting a farm is a process. While the field is set to go into cover crop come March 2013, construction on the high tunnel is contingent upon adequate funds.

Here's where we are:

We currently have...

  • half an acre of land (in the form of an old asparagus patch) set aside on UNL's East Campus
  • the ability to till and rid the former asparagus field of...well...asparagus
  • donated organic cover crop seed (thanks Albert Lea!) to cover the soon-to-be exposed field and hoop house floor
  • access to greenhouse and organic farming experts at UNL and experienced community garden staff members from Community CROPS

Here's where we want to be:

  • equipped with a fully-functional hoop house to compliment our current field space
  • ready to start growing!
Fix me!

Here's where we need your help:

Materials needed to renovate the hoop house:

  • covering material with appropriate light transmission to replace the current hoop house plastic
  • untreated wood/recycled plastic lumber to replace the current baseboards, hip boards, and door/entryway (if we exceed our funding goal, we can consider steel instead of lumber!)
  • miscellaneous parts (bolts, nails, drill bits, small tools)
  • seed

 

With your support, after a year of preparation the land will be ready for its first vibrant season and bountiful harvest--feeding both the community and students' drive for knowledge while also fulfilling the mission of Community CROPS: (Combining Resources, Opportunities, and People for Sustainability) helping people work together to grow healthy food and live sustainably.

 

Thank you!

 

Note: all contributions will show up as going toward Community CROPS, our fund manager.

story:
Short Summary

Seven US Marines were killed in an accident Monday night. We can never be consoling enough in these situations, but at least we can show these families that we appreciate their sacrifice by helping them out in such a gesture.

Every penny of every donation will go straight to the families for help with funeral expenses, and to help their children go to school.

There are many other donation services you can go through, but our donations are not filtered through a corporation, or divided out through multiple services. The focal point of this campaign are the seven families who are devastated by their loss. No matter how big or small the donation, anything can help.

story:
You are just a few clicks away from making good men better men!

That is the true power of your gift. The Fraternity is able to do more for collegiate members because of men like you, thank you! Your gift goes to immediate use – it may be used for scholarships, leadership training, or to support the staff effort to shape men who lead with values.

You're about to do something really special;  What better feeling is there than supporting men, knowing that your gift may just change their lives?

story:
We are Kahina and Aissa Rabbaoui

We are sister and brother, 11 and 13 years-old and live in Berlin, Germany. One summer, we learned about an important time in Moroccan history in the 1920s  that no one talks about.  We researched film archives and learned more through all that was available to us at no cost. There is so much available! We decided to make a documentary about it to bring it to public attention again.

The film is called, The Return of the Repressed.  Here is the trailer:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=59muKta5Z8k&feature=youtu.be

We learned a lot about what each of us likes to do. For example, Kahina took naturally to art direction; while Aissa, lead in requests and editing.  We both worked on the story and found that we're a great team together.  We want to visit you at your school or organization and find out about you.  Invite us to your school!

Most of all, we want to meet people our age.  We want to talk about how exciting and important to us to decide to do something, research it, and finish a project like this documentary.  We learned that no matter how young we are, we can still make a contribution that matters.

Our film will show in San Francisco, on the weekend of 17-18 October with the Arab Film Festival, www.arabfilmfestival.com.  We would like your help to get to San Francisco with our father, Youssef, so we can present our work to you in person and exchange with you. 

A note from Katy Kavanaugh, filmmaker/curator, Stanford M. Ed:

"People growing up in today's connected world are international peers and are naturally curious about each other. I find Aissa and Kahina's work together is unique and inspiring, especially for other children. Their conviction is accessible and their love for each other is contagious.  Oftentimes, a young person's fresh view on history provides fresh insights for contemporary challenges as it has here. Cross-cultural exchange with other children who have managed to do such things with the resources at hand is an invaluable learning opportunity.  Cinema is a powerful medium of exchange, especially when the power behind it is coming from thoughtful young minds. We should expect more great things from this team."

Your contributions will support our airfare, housing, transportation in the Bay Area for ten days. 

$3640 three round-trip tickets Berlin - San Francisco ($1200 ea.)

$800 accommodations with AirBnB

$1000 meals and transportation ($100/day for 3)

$350  incidentals, campaign reward costs

If there are ways you might be able to help us cut our costs, please tell us. We appreciate your help in getting the word out - please Tweet and Post freely!

story:
Who I Am

I'm a 29 year-old female university student and I love movies!

I'm pursuing a Bachelor of Arts from The University of King's College and Dalhousie University. I'm taking an English Honours program with a Film Studies minor. 

I have been freelancing for FRANK Magazine since 2011 and recently started writing for Halifax's alternative weekly newspaper, The Coast. My contributions to the Arts section include DVD reviews. The first DVD review I wrote was one of the most wonderful occasions in my academic and professional career. 

I never want to stop writing about film.

Why I Want Your Dollars 

There's a film class happening at the University of Toronto this summer titled "Special Topics in Genre and Modes: B Movies and Cult Cinema." I've been accepted to the University of Toronto. I have the time and motivation but I can't attend without financial assistance.

This class will bring me one step closer to finishing the longest BA in history. More than that, this opportunity will contribute to my academic, professional, and personal development beyond anything I could have hoped for this summer.

What I Need

Let me break it down for you fine folks: I need $4000 CAD to fund this academic adventure. 

Application: $100

Tuition: $1400

Residence: $1600

Flight: $500

Food: $400

Total: $4000

I have been awarded $1500 CAD from the lovely people who administrate the Fountain School of Performing Arts Summer Program Awards. 

I am able to contribute $500 CAD straight from my lint-filled pockets. 

That leaves $2000 CAD that I need to fill and that's where you come in.

Every little bit helps. Check your couch cushions, look in your piggy bank, add-up the coins in your change purse, anything at all... I'll take it!

Other Ways To Help Me

I know some of you don't have any extra money but that doesn't mean you can't help me. Please, please, please, use the Indiegogo share tools! Share my campaign on your social networks! Tell your friends and family! Heck, tell the guy at the ATM who's flipping through a wad of twenties!

What I'm Gonna Do 

As a testament to my academic adventure in Canada's biggest city, and as special thanks to all my donors, I'm making a zine about my experience.


Why You Should Contribute

If you contribute to my campaign you'll receive a thank you in my zine, a copy of my zine and an invitation to my zine drop party!

If you pick a perk then you'll receive all of the above plus your perk!

If you contribute you'll feel warm fuzzies, be part of my zine, and support my academic adventure! 

Help me reach my goal!

Thank you.

story:
Thank you for your help! I'd like to attend my graduation in Buffalo, NY. I am graduating with a Masters in The Public Understanding of Science. Unfortunately, my income is in the poverty range so I cannot make it to Buffalo. I am hopeful that this degree may afford me better opportunities in the informal science education sector so that I can get a decent job. Any funds over the amount will be used as a personal scholarship towards me earning my PhD in Science Education which I start in June.

I need to purchase plane tickets for my wife and I: $200.00 each

Hotel Expenses: $ 130

Cap and Gown and accessories: $100

Taxi: $60

Food: $40.00

______________

Total: $730

An even $800 would cover any unexpected expenses and days missed from work.

Please help. I do not wish to miss this event. This is a very big deal for me.

 

Thanks to all of my family, friends, fans, allies, and concerned people.

story:
I have created this campaign on behalf of my younger brother and his three young children. We are raising funds to cover the legal cost so the children could be freed from undertaking heavy religious responsibilities on a daily basis. Please contribute and share this campaign with people in your network.

The Children and their Religious Responsibilities

My brother and his children live in Melbourne, Australia. He is the father of three beautiful girls – the sunshine of his life. Do you have children? And if so, do you believe they should be free to learn, play and have fun as children instead of praying 5 times a day, recite holy Quran every day and wear hijab at the ages of 5 and 10? If you said yes, then I really need your help.

In January 2003, my brother and his wife separated. Until final court orders, the children live with their mother. Over a two year period and without my brother’s knowledge, the wife converted to a fundamentalist Muslim by a local Islamic group who believe in the practice of Sharia (Islamic) law. The girls – who are 10 year old twins and a 5 year old – are now being coerced by their mother to pray 5 times a day, during the night, even in their lunch break at school. Children are also instructed to recite holy Quran every day and wear hijab in public and at school. A major part of children’s day is taken away to undertake religious observances.

My brother doesn’t believe that such young children should be brainwashed and forced into practicing religious rituals mandated only for Muslim adults. He wishes to see the children learning, playing and participating in extracurricular activities and just enjoying being children. When they are adults, they can decide for themselves which particular religious ritual they want to practice and how often. For now, the kids should be allowed to be just kids without heavy religious responsibilities.

Children have rights and parents and adults have responsibilities. Children rights are being abused in the name of religion and political correctness. You can put a stop to this!

Legal Fees

So I am helping my brother raising money for the legal fees to fight for his children’s religious freedom. He has a 1-day court hearing in March 2014 and a 4-day hearing in June 2014 where his legal team will argue that his ex-wife has no right to indoctrinate, instruct and force the children to practice adult-like heavy religious practices on a daily basis. It’s a big issue which will require expert academic and religious evidence and the legal fees are very expensive. I would like to raise about $40,000 alone to pay for the legal team. Can you help?

I can’t offer gifts for your kind donations but a promise to send hugs from the children and their hand-drawn digitally converted artworks. You will have full commercial rights to these artworks. You will be contributing to an issue of international importance and towards the future of 3 very special girls. Please help if you share our view that kids should be free to be kids, it is their right.

Please help in the best interest of the children.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, just spreading the word to everyone you know is just as valuable! Please share this campaign with people in your social network by Facebook, Twitter or or by good old fashioned email. Thank you, your help will be much appreciated.
story_txt:
I have created this campaign on behalf of my younger brother and his three young children. We are raising funds to cover the legal cost so the children could be freed from undertaking heavy religious responsibilities on a daily basis. Please contribute and share this campaign with people in your network.The Children and their Religious ResponsibilitiesMy brother and his children live in Melbourne, Australia. He is the father of three beautiful girls – the sunshine of his life. Do you have children? And if so, do you believe they should be free to learn, play and have fun as children instead of praying 5 times a day, recite holy Quran every day and wear hijab at the ages of 5 and 10? If you said yes, then I really need your help.In January 2003, my brother and his wife separated. Until final court orders, the children live with their mother. Over a two year period and without my brother’s knowledge, the wife converted to a fundamentalist Muslim by a local Islamic group who believe in the practice of Sharia (Islamic) law. The girls – who are 10 year old twins and a 5 year old – are now being coerced by their mother to pray 5 times a day, during the night, even in their lunch break at school. Children are also instructed to recite holy Quran every day and wear hijab in public and at school. A major part of children’s day is taken away to undertake religious observances.My brother doesn’t believe that such young children should be brainwashed and forced into practicing religious rituals mandated only for Muslim adults. He wishes to see the children learning, playing and participating in extracurricular activities and just enjoying being children. When they are adults, they can decide for themselves which particular religious ritual they want to practice and how often. For now, the kids should be allowed to be just kids without heavy religious responsibilities.Children have rights and parents and adults have responsibilities. Children rights are being abused in the name of religion and political correctness. You can put a stop to this! Legal FeesSo I am helping my brother raising money for the legal fees to fight for his children’s religious freedom. He has a 1-day court hearing in March 2014 and a 4-day hearing in June 2014 where his legal team will argue that his ex-wife has no right to indoctrinate, instruct and force the children to practice adult-like heavy religious practices on a daily basis. It’s a big issue which will require expert academic and religious evidence and the legal fees are very expensive. I would like to raise about $40,000 alone to pay for the legal team. Can you help?I can’t offer gifts for your kind donations but a promise to send hugs from the children and their hand-drawn digitally converted artworks. You will have full commercial rights to these artworks. You will be contributing to an issue of international importance and towards the future of 3 very special girls. Please help if you share our view that kids should be free to be kids, it is their right.Please help in the best interest of the children.

Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't contribute financially, just spreading the word to everyone you know is just as valuable! Please share this campaign with people in your social network by Facebook, Twitter or or by good old fashioned email. Thank you, your help will be much appreciated.

story:
About MyPsych

At MyPsych, we believe that everybody should have access to mental health tools and resources. We create technology with the purpose of improving users’ mental health and cultivating positive emotional wellbeing.

1/3 of Americans suffer from a mental illness.  

50% of those with a mental illness do not seek treatment.

60% remain untreated.  

Our vision is to create a mobile application and website system for students and school counselors, meant to facilitate mental health communication and improvement. With MyPsych, students will be able to actively promote their mental and emotional health.

Any student will be able to increase emotional awareness, create goals, and track progress using the MyPsych mobile app. Students will also be able to access mental health resources or communicate directly with their school counselor or therapist directly from the app.  

What We’ve Already Accomplished

In 2012, the MyPsych app was released and garnered over 30,000 users and a 4.5 average rating in the Apple app store.

Subsequently, the MyPsych Therapy End System (TES), a free website for therapists to access their patients’ MyPsych app data, was launched.

In October 2013, the Substance and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) bought the rights to include the MyPsych app in the National Suicide Lifeline mobile application.

We recently released the interactive MyPsych Suicide Intervention website, designed to help prevent an individual from committing suicide. The website also includes a free online safety plan creator tool. Similar platforms for drug and alcohol abuse are in development. 

iMyPsych – Why We Need Your Help

In order to round out the MyPsych system, our next step is to develop iMyPsych, a website where any individual can pursue self-help and self-improvement. Users will be able to identify challenges, track variables, analyze trends, and create a roadmap for self improvement. At the same time, the website will give access to health resources –meditation webinars, yoga classes, video conferencing with mental health professionals— guiding users to a healthier state of mind.

Students using the school-specific iMyPsych platform will be able to communicate directly with school therapists, counselors, and support, as well as access other resources.  

Resources, such as articles and online classes, will be recommended to users based on their data. Therapists, psychiatrists, counselors, and other professionals will add resources to the platform.

To accompany the iMyPsych platform, we are developing technology to be used in conjunction with health sensor wristbands. This technology will export data about your physical readings (think heart rate and respiratory rate) to iMyPsych. This data can be used to show correlations between your physical state and psychological state— for example, you could choose to alert yourself about a panic attack an hour before it occurs. This will be accomplished using adaptive algorithms and results from recent studies. 

The iMyPsych User Experience

Variables such as mood, stress, and relationships satisfaction can be recorded using different tools. Some tools will track variables automatically, such as sunset time and weather. There are many smartphone apps for health tracking, journaling, and goal setting; iMyPsych is the place where all of these tools are brought together into one integrated platform. The portal is configurable. For example, after seeing a correlation between daylight hours and mood, a user might add the Seasonal Affective tracker to their portal.

Challenges

Our biggest risk and challenge is not moving quickly enough.

At MyPsych, we believe our tenacity, focus, and care has guided us through adversity and will continue to do so.

Foresight is helpful too; security is always important in the mental health industry and the educational system. MyPsych is HIPAA compliant. Data is encrypted, backed-up, and secure. Purchasers will own all rights to their data, and MyPsych will be interfaced with other health records and databases.

Raising $50,000 to build iMyPsych

We are hoping to raise $50,000 to complete the iMyPsych public platform and customize iMyPsych for students and schools.  

We know that your contribution means that you care about our goal as much as we do. We know that every contribution has its own story behind it, and we want your story to be a part of this product.

We hope that our rewards make you feel involved in promoting mental health and cultivating positive wellbeing in our communities.  

Thank you,

the MyPsych Team

*MyPsych does NOT diagnose or attempt to treat any illness.

*MyPsych is NOT self-help material - it is a free platform for self-help and self-improvement. iMyPsych for students / schools will not contain any resources except those requested / provided by the school / university / staff for students.

story:
Finally... an answer to "What did you do in school today?" Communicate the school day home. Help us build the Wink App so you can better help your kids!

Simple

The Wink App is a new, convenient, no-hassel educational app built around communicating the school day back to families. Web and mobile options allow teachers quick access to sending one-way messages home to parents. Parents receive the messages in their email in-box or on their mobile device. Informal and relaxed. Just the good stuff so you can help your kids.

Key Features of the Wink App

  • Focused: geared toward early childhood through middle school students and families
  • Informational: built with the goal of helping school come home
  • Seamless: ease of use for teachers and for families is our priority
  • Functional: informal, one-way messages starting with the teachers 
  • Available: teachers login online or via the mobile app and send to family preferred smartphones or an email in-box

What does Wink do for YOU?

For Families and Students

  • Lessons make their way home unobtrusively 
  • Parents are better informed, so in turn can help their children more effectively
  • Generate better performance by students knowing that their teacher and family are working as a team.
  • Greater continuity between home and school

For Teachers

  • Save time! No need for newsletters any longer. Keep all families or individual families current with a no hassle, 60 sec message sent from your mobile phone or computer.
  • Less misscomunication and questions from parents.
  • Improved relationships with families. 
  • Send individualized updates on a particular student to families each day, every few days, or weekly.

The Questions

  • How would knowing more about the school day change your conversations with your children at home?
  • If you knew more about what happened in school, would your children be better students? Would they be happier?
  • Would more communication from the classroom home, positively affect a teacher's own performance?


Who We Are

We are educators, working with more educators, families, professionals and software developers to build a company acutely focused on needs in education today. We are dedicated to building innovative resources that incite and excite learning. Our products are created by rethinking current educational issues and concerns. Others, come from our passion to expand the current learning environment. With our Wink App, we aim to fill families in on what their children do during the school day. We were founded in early 2013. Wink is our first product.

We are Educate Einstein. www.educateeinstein.com


How Wink Will Change the World!!! Or at least, let a whole bunch of kids know we care.

Teachers don't need research to tell them (although it does) that families who are well-informed and involved in their children's education, more often raise kids who are successful students. One of the main challenges we face however, is less and less time in our day. This makes communication between school and home much more difficult. We think in this day and age, we should be able to do better. So…we built Wink.


What We Will Use the Funds For

Any funds raised from this campaign will go directly to the final build and testing phase of the Wink App. We have the great people at Zco Corporation ready to build our app!  Our problem is that the well of funds for this project has nearly dried-up! Please participate by donating and/or passing the campaign along!

Main Elements Covered In The Build

  • UI Design and Document
  • HTML Work 
  • Graphics
  • Web Service Integration
  • Development of Parent Module


Links to Check Out

  • Educate Einstein homepage: http://educateeinstein.com
  • Home to the Wink App: http://educateeinstein.com/wink-app.html
  • Research Behind the Wink App: 
  1. http://www.ksbe.edu/spi/PDFS/Reports/Family_involvement.pdf
  2. http://www.ode.state.or.us/initiatives/familycommunity/files/researchfaminvolstdntachieve.pdf
  • Our Developers: http://www.zco.com


Our Pay It Forward Project!

As a way for us to "pay it forward," we are making our own effort to creatively make a difference. We are spreading the good in this world by giving away random acts of kindness! What could a paid cup of coffee or covered fare to send a package do for others? We can tell you, at the very least, it makes people smile. After that? We believe one good deed deserves another.  

Keep an eye on it through our Facebook page or on our website. There will be a special recognition section and a list of how we are paying it forward to others.  


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate toward our project this year, please… pretty please… contribute and help us out by telling everyone you know! We would be forever grateful!

story:
What is this campaign about?

Hello/Sawatdee Kup/Sabaidee, My name is Christopher Jilley. Two very good friends of mine David Burrows and Chris Corbett and I have visited Thailand, Laos and SE Asia a number of times and have ridden around much of Thailand and Laos by Motorcycle. During our visit's we have always been overwhelmed by the beauty and friendliness of the people of Laos. Given the hardship and loss the country and its people have endured over the years, being the most bombed country on earth, the love and friendship the Laos people are so willing to share is so Inspiring. The children of Laos want so much to learn and some travel long distances to attend schools with very little equipment to assist in their learning other than of course the vital support provided by the devoted families and teachers.

We realise that we can only do a little, but a little goes a very long way! We have raised funds through our workplaces and friends and our own donations so far to raise funds to purchase school/sports equipment as well as bicycles to give to schools to help their students get to school where no public transport is available or can be afforded.

We invite you to join us on our Tour via our Blog http://illyjay.blogspot.com.au/ where from November 1st 2013 to November 24th 2013 we will be riding around these beautiful countries and down the Ho Chi Minh trails in Southern Laos, bringing a book party to a School as well as later in the trip donating Bicycles to a school(s) in Luang Prabang.

If you are able to and willing to support us in this good cause we promise you it will make a difference!

We will of course post receipts for the purchases with 100% of the money raised going directly to the people of Laos in the form of School Equipment and/or Bicycles. When we arrive in Luang Prabang at the end of this campaign and we will see how many more bicycles we can/it makes sense to purchase and any further left over funds will be used for the next Book Party(s)/Good Cause(s). Whilst David and I only have 3 weeks in Asia this time, our good friend Chris Corbett (Who started Riding Laos for Good Causes and runs http://www.motorcycle-tours-laos.org/ was key in organising all of this) will continue his good cause work after we have left and we are excited about the amazing things that can be done.

David and I are regular visitors to the region and plan to keep visiting regularly to continue Riding for Good Causes and look forward to sharing these experiences with you! :)

See the bottom of this page for links to organisations that inspired us that support the Laos people from education to clearing UXO (Unexploded Ordinance)


What We Need & What You Get

We would love to be able to purchase more equipment/transport for these kids and with your help we can do just that!

You will get the opportunity to follow us on our amazing motorcycle adventure through these beautiful lands and get to share in the joy of helping many children in their development. http://illyjay.blogspot.com.au/


The Impact

Providing Children tools and opportunities they may otherwise not have in their development.

Improving the potential for this beautiful country and its people for generations to come by further investing in education.


Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with as many as you can, a little goes a long way, a little from alot goes a very long way :)

If you are able to, support other charities and good cause organisations working to help the people of Laos and many other countries around the world. Use the links below to learn more about some of these organisations.

Momo Books (Language Learning Resources) - http://www.momobooks.org/

MAG (Mines Advisory Group) - http://www.maginternational.org/

Riding Laos for Good Causes - http://www.motorcycle-tours-laos.org/


Why not visit Laos or Thailand for your next trip abroad? Such amazing places to see and people to meet :) Kop Jai Lai Lai or Kop Kuhn Kup (Thank you)

story:
To celebrate moms this year, Indiegogo and The Miracle Foundation are teaming up to raise $100,000 by May 12th to deliver a happy childhood to a new group of beautiful orphans.  WE did it!  We raised $100,000.  Thank YOU.

Help us bring on our NEXT orphanage of 100 children!

AND NOW,  you can get two mom's for the price of one!  To honor their mother,  Mrs. Peggy Brunet Ahuja,  Ranika Cohen and Rajan Ahuja are matching every donation up to $25,000! 

Now you can give a Mother’s Day gift she’ll NEVER forget.  Instead of flowers, honor that special mom by giving a real home to abandoned boys and girls…who will sing her praises too!  

ALL GIFTS BOUGHT BEFORE 11:59 EST ON MOTHERS DAY WILL RECEIVE A BEAUTIFULLY DESIGNED EMAIL CARD ON MOTHER'S DAY--TO SEND OR PRINT FOR THE HONORED MOM (See perks). GIFTS BOUGHT AFTER THAT TIME WILL BE SENT A CARD ON MONDAY, MAY 13, 2013.

 

 

 

What They Need & What You Get:

They Need A Loving Housemother:  $100

You get good karma, an 'Honor a Mom' e-card and a video

 

They Need Food - $25

You get good karma and an "Honor a Mom" e-card

 

 

They Need Healthcare - $50 

You get good karma, an "Honor a Mom" e-card and a photo of a child

 

They Need To Learn English - $100

You get good karma, an "Honor a Mom" e-card and a photo of a child

 

They Need An Education - $500

 You get good karma, an "Honor a Mom" e-card and a photo of a video

 

They Need Clean Water - $1000

You get good karma, an "Honor a Mom" e-card and a call from our Founder to a special Mom on Mother's Day

 

They Need A Licensed Social Worker Who Lives Onsite:  $2500

You get good karma, an "Honor a Mom" e-card and a call from our Founder to a special Mom on Mother's Day

 

Other ways you can help!

  • Personally share our story-Please tell two people about this campaign and our work. Word of mouth and your endorsement is powerful. Thank you!

 

  • Use the share tools at the bottom of this page. Craft and email to send to friends.                                                                                

 

  • Like us on Facebook-The Miracle Foundation   Please share and comment on   our posts.

 

  • Follow us on twitter-@TheMiracleFound tweet our stories and success

 

  • Travel to India (to meet the children). Next trip is September 2013.

 

  • Invite us to speak to your church or school.

Volunteer with us we are fun!

  • We need experienced grant writers, film directors and script writers, social media mavens or masters, clever web designers, graphic designers, infographics experts and visual illustrators.

Call or email us:

I would love to speak with you to answer any questions and tell you more about the beautiful, delightful children.  Kerry at 512 329-8635  or email me: kerry@miraclefoundation.org

 

Please share our campaign. Help us get featured on the indiegogo home page.

Help us bring on our NEXT orphanage of 100 children!
AND NOW,  you can get two mom's for the price of one!  To honor their mother,  Mrs. Peggy Brunet Ahuja,  Ranika Cohen and Rajan Ahuja are matching every donation up to $25,000! 
Now you can give a Mother’s Day gift she’ll NEVER forget.  Instead of flowers, honor that special mom by giving a real home to abandoned boys and girls…who will sing her praises too!  
ALL GIFTS BOUGHT BEFORE 11:59 EST ON MOTHERS DAY WILL RECEIVE A BEAUTIFULLY DESIGNED EMAIL CARD ON MOTHER'S DAY--TO SEND OR PRINT FOR THE HONORED MOM (See perks). GIFTS BOUGHT AFTER THAT TIME WILL BE SENT A CARD ON MONDAY, MAY 13, 2013.
 
 
 
What They Need & What You Get:
They Need A Loving Housemother:  $100


You get good karma, an 'Honor a Mom' e-card and a video
 
They Need Food - $25

You get good karma and an "Honor a Mom" e-card
 
 
They Need Healthcare - $50 

You get good karma, an "Honor a Mom" e-card and a photo of a child
 
They Need To Learn English - $100

You get good karma, an "Honor a Mom" e-card and a photo of a child
 
They Need An Education - $500
 You get good karma, an "Honor a Mom" e-card and a photo of a video
 
They Need Clean Water - $1000
You get good karma, an "Honor a Mom" e-card and a call from our Founder to a special Mom on Mother's Day
 
They Need A Licensed Social Worker Who Lives Onsite:  $2500

You get good karma, an "Honor a Mom" e-card and a call from our Founder to a special Mom on Mother's Day
 
Other ways you can help!

Personally share our story-Please tell two people about this campaign and our work. Word of mouth and your endorsement is powerful. Thank you!

 

Use the share tools at the bottom of this page. Craft and email to send to friends.                                                                                

 

Like us on Facebook-The Miracle Foundation   Please share and comment on   our posts.

 

Follow us on twitter-@TheMiracleFound tweet our stories and success

 

Travel to India (to meet the children). Next trip is September 2013.

 

Invite us to speak to your church or school.

Volunteer with us we are fun!

We need experienced grant writers, film directors and script writers, social media mavens or masters, clever web designers, graphic designers, infographics experts and visual illustrators.

Call or email us:
I would love to speak with you to answer any questions and tell you more about the beautiful, delightful children.  Kerry at 512 329-8635  or email me: kerry@miraclefoundation.org
 
Please share our campaign. Help us get featured on the indiegogo home page.

story:
The mission of Children’s Orchestra of DC is to motivate youth to stay in school through quality, accessible and affordable ensemble-based music education that contributes to their social and academic growth. Inspired by El Sistema, CODC currently serves 22 students from Garrison Elementary School learning violin, viola, or cello after school.  These young musicians come together as an orchestra for 2.5 hours every weekday, focusing on the values of teamwork and community. Our time together is filled with instrumental rehearsals, choir practice, homework assistance, and lots of fun!  After just four weeks, our students put on their first concert!

     Garrison Elementary School is a Title I DC Public School, which is why Children's Orchestra of DC is offered free-of-charge to all students. Each student is given an instrument, sheet music, and supplies to use throughout the year. CODC is proud to offer this quality childcare program every afternoon that parents can afford. After our first performance, word quickly spread within the community about our program and we now have a long wait list of children who want to join the orchestra. CODC has received instrument donations from several organizations. Many of these instruments are sitting in our music room waiting to be played by an excited child! 

     Our program is currently taught by volunteers. In order to expand and serve more students, we need to hire an additional Teaching Artist. With your generous support, we plan to do just that! Every dollar that you donate will go towards hiring a quality Teaching Artist that can work with new students throughout the week. Even if you cannot contribute directly to our campaign, please help these students by spreading the word and sharing our story! You can use the Indiegogo share tools below or simply copy-and-paste the web address of this page onto Facebook, Twitter, or e-mail. Please help us positively impact children in DC!

story:
Training women in rural northern Ghana to be potters helps preserve their traditional culture and gives them income-generating skills.

WE'VE REACHED $4000. WHAT'S NEXT?

Training more potters does no good if they don't have places to sell them. SWOPA would love to be able to show their work at Le Salon International de l'Artisant de Ouagadougou, an international arts and crafts fair in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso. (That's the next country to the north. Ouagadougou is about 1/2 a day away.) In the past it's been prohibitively expensive, but last year some of them went to check it out. (See the photo.) Money raised over $4000 would help them have a booth at the 2014 fair.

SOME BACKGROUND

The people of Sirigu in northern Ghana are culturally rich but economically poor. The village is known for its indigenous architecture, pottery and wall designs. They maintain a traditional lifestyle. Many still live in intricately painted mud houses. Changing weather patterns, however, have hurt their agrarian economy, and new sources of income are needed. The revival of its traditional arts has become an important source of revenue. Additional income from pottery helps Sirigu women pay for school fees, food and other needs of their families.

Pottery is central to the culture of the women. Besides creating it for their own domestic and ritual uses, the women sell it in local markets. Like the designs on their houses, their pottery has symbolic designs, telling stories and often invoking the protection of the gods. 

In the past, girls learned pottery in their home, but fewer are now learning this way. SWOPA, the Sirigu Women's Association of Pottery and Art, has been developing new markets for pottery, enabling pottery sales to be a more signifiant part of a family's income. 

I first visited Sirigu in 2007 and have been back twice since. When I was there in January, 2013, I asked the potters what I could do to help. They requested that I raise money to finance a program to train young women to be potters.

THE TRAINING PROGRAM

The training program will be made available to women in the village between the ages of 20 and 35 to assure that Sirigu's traditional pottery making skills are transferred to a younger generation.

  • Four thousand dollars provides a month-long training program for 10 women, funding two experienced trainers and materials. 
  • Besides learning to make traditional pots, trainers will teach the women marketing and business skills. 
  • The women will also learn something completely new to the village – to fire their pots in a new community kiln. Currently pots are fired in a large bonfire. The next generation of potters needs to know how to use a kiln and fire to higher temperatures. Higher-fired pots can be transported without breaking to markets in larger cities to the south, giving the potters a broader customer base.

SWOPA - The Sirigu Women's Organization for Pottery and Art

In 1997, the Sirigu Women’s Organization of Pottery and Art (SWOPA) was founded, with the aim of preserving traditional culture and increasing their income through ecotourism and the sale of their pottery and art. Since its founding in 1997, the goal of SWOPA has been to produce high quality pottery that has its roots in the village culture. SWOPA has built an arts center where it sells the work of local potters, established tourist accommodations including guest rooms in traditionally decorated huts, and a restaurant. It provides guided tours of the village and workshops in pottery, basket weaving and drumming. They are moving towards marketing their pottery to galleries and hotels in the larger cities to the south.

ABOUT ANN

I am a studio potter living near Boston. My work is inspired by traditional crafts around the world. As I've traveled, I’ve gained an understanding that in underdeveloped countries, people rich in culture often lack the basics for physical well being, having only minimal food, shelter, education and health care. 


I try to make connections with the potters I meet. The most enduring of these connections has been with the potters of Sirigu. SWOPA’s extraordinary artwork and commitment to preserving their culture are a continual inspiration to me. I was delighted when they asked if I could help them raise money to train more young women to be potters.

PERKS 

$25 - A thank you e-card from the people of Sirigu featuring one of their paintings

Ann's making special pottery for the next 3 perks:
$50 - An e-card and a small dish with a Sirigu-inspired design

$100 - An e-card, and another small dish with an African animal made by Ann

$150 - Two dishes and a tea bowl with Sirigu-inspired design. Made by Ann.

$250 - All of the above plus a painting like the one in the e-card (but suitable for framing) done by the Sirigu women.

$500 - Everything above plus either a 2-hour pottery lesson for 4 people at Ann's studio (in Randolph, MA, USA) or Ann will make large  platter or bowl specially for you.

story:
About Me

Hi! I’m Brooklyn Holbrook. I’m a passionate, dedicated, loving girl who is just looking to fulfill God’s plan for my life. This trip to Togo, Africa is just the start to the amazing journey that I know God has ahead for me.

My past semester at Lee University, I started as a Business major. At the end of the semester, within two weeks time I changed my major to Intercultural Studies (Missions work) with a Business minor. I also met the missionary couple that I would be going on my trip with the very next week. During this time, I was in consistent prayer, desperate for God to reveal to me what he desired for my life. I know that this opportunity is not a coincidence, but it is a divine appointment from God. This will be a life changing experience, and your contribution would allow this transformation to begin to take place.

  • I could attempt to explain to you what your donation would mean to me, but I do not think that I could even begin to cover the surface. On this trip, I will encounter children of all ages, families of all numbers. All of these individuals have one thing in common: they are in need of wholistic miracles. They need food, CLEAN water, medical help, love, encouragement, and most of all, they need to know Jesus Christ. By donating towards this trip, you would allow hundreds, even thousands of people in Togo to have the opportunity to get this wholisitic healing.



What We Need & What You Get

Here is the break down:

  • There are many things that the donations would be going towards. $4,500 is not just a number. That includes the flights, down payments, registration fees, the housing, the food required to bring to Africa, vaccination costs, medications, a camera, luggage bags, travel toiletries and hygiene products, etc. 
    - $4,020 is the exact cost of the trip itself. This would cover flights, down payments, registration fees, and housing. Everything else is required by the missionary to come up with on their own. Deadlines for my payments are on April 27th, 2014 and June 27th, 2014.
    - I am also required to get a yellow fever vaccination before leaving. In order to make sure I will be safe in Togo, it is recommended to get at least 3 more shots. This can get pretty costly. (Which vaccinations? Take a look here: Health Information for Travelers to Togo)

  • I bet you’re thinking, “What will I get out of this?” Well, good news! Any donation you make towards this trip is TAX DEDUCTIBLE! All you have to do is make sure you do not submit anonymously when you donate online. After the campaigns are over, I will get the names of the donors and contact each one with the information and where to send it to get your tax deduction.

  • Even if the goal is not reached financially, the money will still go towards the trip. I will be making campaigns to raise money until the trip deadlines. If one campaign is over, you will still have a chance to donate!

The Impact

  • Not only does this trip to Africa expose people to God’s love, but it also involves bringing about a change of the living conditions in Togo. Innocent people are suffering every day from the contaminated water there and as a result, many children are orphaned daily. Mentor Leaders continues to work hard to supply clean water, provide homes for the orphans, and they are educating them to grant them the same opportunity for a thriving life. 

  • Traveling with a worship choir at Lee, I have been able to witness the lasting impact that ministry makes on people’s lives. I desire to see that same change in these people’s lives. Please know that by donating to this cause, you would be investing into a child's eternity. 



Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help! Some other ways to make this dream come to life:


  • Spread the word! The more exposure of this trip, the better.
  • Share this campaign on your social media. Your friends are your friends for a reason!
  • One of the most important things: Partner with me in prayer. For the kids, the missionaries, the circumstances. I believe in the power of prayer. 

If you have ANY questions or concerns feel free to contact me bholbr00@leeu.edu.

Want to know more information about Mentor Leaders? Click here!

* If you donate $250 or more, you will get to choose a Jamie Holbrook original artwork or photo print from her website for free!
(Click the above link to browse the art!)

story:
Introducing Go!


What is Virtuali?

Virtuali (pronounced “virtually”) is a leadership training firm that helps companies recruit, develop, and retain emerging leaders in the Millennial (or Gen-Y) demographic through our Go! program.

What is the Go! program?

Go! is an international immersion program that teaches leadership and cross-cultural fluency.

For 30, 60, or 90 days, participants travel abroad to one of our international campuses where they participate in an immersive learning curriculum that combines e-learning, seminars at top universities, and hands-on business practicums.

The best part is… employees continue to work remotely for their current employer throughout the duration of the program! (It’s like going to business school at night except much, much better.)

While Go! is open to everyone, we designed it specifically to align with Millennials’ career aspirations and professional development needs. More on that below!

Why would a company offer the Go! program? 

We provide 3 very important benefits to companies.

#1 – We improve employee recruitment.

We’ve done our research (and we happen to be Millennials ourselves). What we’ve found is that Millennials want three things at work:

1.  Learning opportunities

2.  International experience

3.  Flexibility

By offering Go!, companies can provide all three, regardless of the company’s size, industry, or geographic reach. That means that they will be able to recruit better prospects (even if they may not be able to compete based on salary and other benefits).

#2 – We help employees develop professionally.

We built Go! from the ground up to address the needs of emerging Millennial leaders today. Our curriculum focuses on developing leadership and communication skills in virtual and global business contexts.

Everything we do is immersive, interactive, and collaborative. We understand how people learn, and we believe passionately that there is no substitute for experience.

We do not provide check-the-box webinars. Nor do we offer cookie-cutter leadership courses. We are a completely new and innovative program, and our goal is to provide meaningful experiences that foster personal and professional growth for our participants.

#3 – We help companies improve employee retention.

Millennials are now the largest segment of the U.S. workforce, and they change jobs A LOT. In fact, 91% of Millennials leave their jobs before three years, which costs companies an average of nearly $25,000 per employee. In many cases, it’s much more.

Go! improves employee retention in two ways.

First, it makes employees more satisfied and engaged. Go! is a unique investment in an employees’ development, and it acts as an incentive and reward for top performers.

Second, companies have the option to include financial incentives (similar to a signing bonus). For example, an employee may have to agree to stay with the company for 6 to 12 months after the program or reimburse the company for some of the program’s cost. (We think this is a fair trade, and it’s one that we would be more than willing to make.)

We need your help!

We have spent the last year building Virtuali. From the beginning, our company has been 100% funded by our founding team. To date, we have developed our curriculum, launched our first campus in Buenos Aires, Argentina, and established key partnerships.

Your donation will ensure that we have enough funding to operate until our first program launches in August 2014. If you would like more details regarding our use of funds, please feel free to email our team directly at info@govirtuali.com.

Please share our Indiegogo page (igg.me/at/govirtuali) with your network and help us reach our goal!

Thank you!

Thank you for helping bring the Go! program to life, we are forever grateful for your support! If you would like to learn more about Virtuali, please feel free to check out our website (govirtuali.com) or send us an email directly (info@govirtuali.com). We’d love to hear from you! 

Sincerely,

The Virtuali Team

use of funds, please feel free to email our team directly at info@govirtuali.com. Please share our Indiegogo page (igg.me/at/govirtuali) with your network and help us reach our goal!
Thank you!
Thank you for helping bring the Go! program to life, we are forever grateful for your support! If you would like to
learn more about Virtuali, please feel free to check out our website (govirtuali.com) or send
us an email directly (info@govirtuali.com). We’d love to hear from you! 
Sincerely,
The Virtuali Team

story:
Run Revolution

Alex, Jewelle, and Nap are community organizers based in Los Angeles. Together, they saw the glittery Hollywood half-marathon on April 5th as a chance to raise funds for the Filipino Migrant Center and the youth solidarity mission to the Philippines this summer. Introducing our runners...

Alex community organizer and staff member, Filipino Migrant Center · born and raised in Tacoma, WA · Pacific Lutheran University (PLU) alumnus, Class of 2006, Cultural Anthropology major · passionate about educating and organizing Filipino migrants, workers, families and youth to advance their rights and welfare · ran first half marathon at Long Beach half marathon in October 2013

Jewelle community organizer, Anakbayan Los Angeles · born in the Philippines, raised in Vegas and LA· Bruin Alumna, Class of 2012, Asian Am major · firm believer in CHANGE · running first 5K (baby steps, ya know)

Nap community organizer, Anakbayan Los Angeles · Manila-born and -raised · member, Pilipino Transfer Student Partnership at UCLA · Bruin geologist, Class of 2014 · loves hiking, outdoors, beer, food, the beach, cooking, indie movies, music · plans to run a full marathon one day

The Beneficiaries

Filipino Migrant

The Filipino Migrant Center (FMC) is a non-profit organization that aims to educate, organize and mobilize the low-income and working-class families of the Filipino community in Southern California and address their issues and concerns. We foster partnerships with individuals, organizations, and communities that share our common interests.

FMC engages the community through education, direct services, capacity-building and campaigns. For more info, click here.

Kapit Bisig Kabataan Network (Youth Link Arms Network)

When Typhoon Haiyan ravaged the central Philippines in November of 2013, Filipino American youth were a powerful force in the grass efforts to quickly respond with a generous outpouring of relief to send back to the Philippines.  Many organizations such as yours held candlelight vigils, hosted fundraisers, and began to advocate for the rights and welfare of the Filipino people when the Philippine government failed to respond.

Kapit Bisig Kabataan Network (KBKN) was formed to unite youth and student organizations to respond to any future disasters in an organized, and systematic fashion in addition to advocating for systemic changes that genuinely impacts the people’s needs. Members of the network work with the National Alliance of Filipino Concerns (NAFCON), a trusted organization that ensures 100% of donations reaches the people most in need, and its partner organization in the Philippines, Bayanihan Alay Sa Sambayanan (BALSA).  


With 21 youth and student organizations from 13 universities across the US, the network is growing each week! TFor more info, click here.

The Impact

You can donate $1, $10 or $100! You may specify if you would like to donate to FMC or KBKN. Otherwise, unspecified donations will be divided (1/3 goes to FMC and 2/3 to KBKN). Donating will:

  • Fund everyday operational expenses as well as special projects of FMC
  • Fund the logistical needs (travel, lodging, etc.) of youth exposurists as well as material support for typhoon survivors

Donating will mean our community work is sustained here in Southern California and in the Philippines. This means FMC will continue to provide much-needed legal and medical services to the South Bay and the Greater LA area and will continue to advocate for game-changing laws like AB 123, AB 241, and the Long Beach Measure N.

For Fil-Am youth, this means that they are connected to the culture and people of our homeland; and as they bring back firsthand experience of being in the homeland, that there will be a new generation of youth organizers to bring change in the U.S. and in the Philippines.

Other Ways You Can Help

Any amount will help. However, if you really do not have the capacity to donate monetarily, feel free to contribute in any of these ways:

  • Educate yourself and others. Better yet, join these community organizations!
  • Help rebuild homes and lives, learn and live with the basic masses in the Philippines this summer and sign up for summer exposure!
  • Be there on the 5th Of April!
  • Share this campaign page!

Let’s go!

story:
Total amount collected will go specifically to the Compassion International Philippines Disaster Relief donation.

On October 30th I saw a post on Facebook by Humans of New York. It is a page dedicated to capturing people’s photo while sharing a personal thought or story, based on the question asked by Brandon (the founder). On this particular day a photo was posted with a lengthy story about how the man in the photo and his wife adopted their first child. After hearing the story, Brandon asked if he could post the full story. The man said yes and then asked if there was any way to raise money for the little boy they had waiting to be adopted as their second child. The goal was to raise $26,000 dollars for this family. In one hour the goal was met. With continued out-pour, Brandon kept the fundraiser open for a period of time that evening. Beginning around 4:00PM, it was closed at 11:59PM. $83,935 dollars was raised in that short window of time for this family. 4,569 funders, an average of $18 dollars donated per person.

I was blown away. After taking a moment of gratitude for those who funded this project, it was no more than a minute later that my thoughts came to those dying of some related cause to starvation every day around the world. Whether it be lack of food or clean water. I thought about what $83,935 dollars could do. And so began my research.

We sponsor children from Compassion International. Compassion International exists as a Christian child advocacy ministry that releases children from spiritual, economic, social and physical poverty and enables them to become responsible, fulfilled Christian adults.

Founded by the Rev. Everett Swanson in 1952, Compassion began providing Korean War orphans with food, shelter, education and health care, as well as Christian training.

Through their online resources I went to their gift catalog where you have the freedom to give according to where you feel led. The first thing that I saw was the title “Safe Water for Life”, clicking through I learned that for $30 dollars you can provide a family with a water well. For $79 dollars you can provide a family with a water filtration system. 1,062 families could have received a water filtration system for the amount of money raised by Humans of New York. In continued research through Compassion I found that for as little as $14 dollars a mother and infant will be provided with food and nutritional supplements for one month. $168 dollars will meet their needs for a year! The options are endless in being able to help, these are just a few to gain perspective.

On November 5th I received a packet in the mail from Compassion with 6 pictures of little children waiting to be sponsored. The cost to sponsor one child is $38 dollars per month. 2,208 children could have been sponsored with the funds raised by Humans of New York.

As I have thought about this issue my mind continues to be boggled by the small percentage of people that gave, raising more than enough funds needed. Imagine if everyone gave? World hunger would be abolished! Something I can't even wrap my head around! And yet when I see something done like raise $83,000 dollars in a short window of time, I have great confidence and hope that it can!

Today more than 50 percent of children alone are bound in the chains of poverty. More than 6 million children die each year from malnutrition. There are more than 9 million deaths related to hunger each year.

Those numbers are staggering. And it’s on my watch. On your watch. If Humans of New York can raise nearly $100,000 dollars in less than a day for one family, why can't we raise enough money to feed the world.

We are approaching a holiday based on thankful giving.

As a follower of Jesus Christ I am called to feed His sheep. Please join me in feeding the sheep of this world by giving.

12,500 children could be sponsored if we reach our goal of raising $1,000,000.

Sound impossible?

Have hope. All things are possible through Christ.

SIDE NOTE: I have been approached on the matter that some people already contribute to Compassion International by way of sponsorship. Begging the question why give here if giving is already happening there?

I created Feed the Sheep in comparison to what Humans of New York did. However, the take away and purpose here is to glorify God in the process of doing something radical for the public to see. I want to put emphasis on the power of those in Christ Jesus and what can happen when the body comes together. I want to take what was done through a secular source and change it into a movement to further God's Kingdom.

Whether you give her or directly to Compassion is your choice. I would simply ask that it be done here to show the world who our God is, and what He is capable of. I believe that Feed the Sheep will not only be a way to conquer poverty, but a way to bring those watching to Christ.

story:
Our Story

For 6 amazing months of my life I lived in a boys orphanage in Klong Toey, a slum of Bangkok.  During this time I was surrounded by children who had been through more than I could imagine but who were happier and more thankful than any I had ever encountered.  The orphanage was one of six that is run by The Human Development Foundation Mercy Centre.  More inspiring than the positivity and strength of the children were the adults who took care of them.  From the house moms and kindergarten teachers to those who found sponsors and raised money, I have never met more generous and dedicated people.  Every single person associated with The Mercy Centre is 100% committed to the poor, the children, the sick, and the entire community.  


Apart from the six orphanages the HDF Mercy Centre also runs slum kindergartens across the city of Bangkok, combats child trafficking, is home to an HIV/AIDS hospice, provides aid to the community, and has opened schools in the island communities as well.  I could go on and on but you can also go to http://mercycentre.org to read about the different projects, see pictures, and hear first hand from Father Joseph Maier, the heart and soul of Mercy.  The Mercy Centre is one big family and the love that flows from person to person is contagious.  They have become my family now and, as it is Christmas, I want to send the best present I can think of: the gift of hope, health, and a future.


As I am sure you all know Thailand sustained immense flooding this year, flooding that ruined houses, destroyed food supplies, put schools out of commission, and caused sickness.  The people of the slums suffered greatly and the Mercy Centre worked diligently to keep the community safe and happy.  Food and resources were stretched thin, but they are a strong group of people and prevailed.  Right now the Mercy Centre is in more need than ever for our love and support to keep everyone staying afloat after the destruction from the flooding.  The Mercy Centre will never turn down a child who needs help regardless of funding or space.  Every cent donated by companies or sponsors goes directly to the those who need it, I can testify to seeing this myself.  Money donated goes to food, clothes, school uniforms and supplies, and healthcare to ensure each child is properly cared for.  


What We Need

My goal is to raise $3000 to send to the Mercy Centre.  This is the estimated amount it takes to provide total care for one year to a child living in one of the Mercy Centre's houses.  Total care when sponsoring a child includes education, food, healthcare, housing, and most importantly LOVE!  Even if we don't make it to $3000 I will send every penny to Father Joe because the Mercy staff will certainly be appreciative of any amount we can give them.  I am in regular contact with Father Joe and the Mercy Centre staff and can guarantee that all money donated will be safely transferred to the foundation.  These are hard times, trust me as a broke law school student I understand, but when I say that every little bit helps I literally mean that every little bit helps.  Please look into your hearts and give the gift of life and love to my brothers and sisters in Thailand during this holiday season.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are interested in making a donation on your own or sponsoring a child yourself please visit www.mercycentre.org and click the link for donations.  There are different levels of sponsorships and you can be in personal contact with the child you support (they make fabulous artwork and letters for their sponsors worth more than any amount of money!)

story:
The Legacy of Loveness

There are many organizations doing great work in Africa including House of Loveness (HoL). One difference with our NGO is that we are focusing on fewer children and using community resources to build programs and opportunities that creates jobs and empowers the children, their families and the local community.

In 2008, filmmaker Betsy Blankenbaker went to Zimbabwe to adopt a baby that had been abandoned. Her name was Loveness. She died as Betsy was arriving in Africa.  Betsy buried Loveness in the fertile soil of Zimbabwe and then promised to never go back.  That same trip,  Betsy met Kuda, Primrose, Cheepo and Tariro. They had also been abandoned.  Kuda was pushing himself across a hospital floor on his hands because he couldn't walk. Betsy thought to herself, Okay just one more trip to Zimbabwe to bring Kuda a wheelchair.

That was nearly four years ago and Kuda is now playing soccer and going to school.  It was all possible through House of Loveness, an NGO which Betsy founded after burying Loveness and which is supported through donations of money and supplies from hundreds of House of Loveness heroes all over the world.

In 2010, HoL helped open a school that gave the children the opportunity to start their education.  There are now 30-36 children attending the year-round school. HoL is now ready to empower the older children in our program through the gift of a private boarding school education in Zimbabwe.

Kuda, Primrose and Brighton are all ready to start boarding school in September. Tariro and Cheepo will follow them a year later.

We realize that greater opportunities in life will come for the children through receiving a private school education. We believe in the future of these children. Do you?

What We Need & What You Get

We desire that our 8 and 9 year old HoL children start private boarding school (with your help) in September 2012.  The annual school fees are $2,400 per child.  The first children to be sponsored for the HoL boarding school program are Primrose, Kuda and Brighton.  When HoL first began supporting these children in 2008, Primrose and Kuda were living in the children's ward of a local hospital. 

Brighton, age 9, is a local boy supported by HoL since 2011. His parents died several years ago and Brighton had been caring for himself and his grandfather when we met him. He had never been to school. With support from HoL and his grandfather's blessing, Brighton is now looking forward to going to boarding school and playing on the soccer team.

And what about you?! By donating to this campaign we have some fantastic perks from postcards from Zimbabwe and artwork by the children to a Service & Safari trip to Zimbabwe for two to visit the House of Loveness children and experience the beauty and soul of Zimbabwe.  Give yourself a bonus perk by visiting Victoria Falls on your way home.

The Impact

HoL supports emergency short-term and long-term needs of at-risk children in Zimbabwe.  Most of the children have been abandoned or orphaned.  Through HoL, the children are living beyond the wounds of their past and growing into happy, empowered children with a future full of possibilites.

In just four years, HoL has helped nearly 100 children through donations to the local hospital, moving abandoned and ophaned children into private housing with local caregivers and paying school fees for children to attend school for the first time in their lives.

Last year, through the successful IndieGoGo campaign Susie's Birthday Wish, over $5,000 was raised to pay the school fees, food and supplies for the HoL children and we celebrated in Zimbabwe with a massive birthday party for London-based House of Loveness hero Susie Sourwine who gifted her annual birthday party to the HoL children. For many of the children, it was their first time to make a wish and blow out the candles on a birthday cake.

The funds raised from the Share Your Heart campaign will go towards private school fees and school supplies for the children. Any additional funds raised from this campaign will go towards to continued support of the school HoL sponsors in Zimbabwe.

Other Ways You Can Help: $10 to Share Your Heart

Please share the IndieGoGo link with your co-workers, school friends, scout troops, Facebook and Twitter followers. We love the idea of one thousand people giving $10 donations each.

And please post your photo on our Facebook page of you Sharing Your Heart for House of Loveness. It's easy: Draw a heart on your hand and take a photo and then post to Facebook or Twitter.

Share Your Heart because you believe in the future of the children of Zimbabwe.

With gratitude and love from Zimbabwe,

House of Loveness

Special thanks to Carole Dean and From The Heart Productions for being the fiscal sponsor of House of Loveness. Your donations to this campaign are tax-deductible (please consult your tax advisor)

Last year, through the successful IndieGoGo campaign Susie's Birthday Wish, over $5,000 was raised to pay the school fees, food and supplies for the HoL children and we celebrated in Zimbabwe with a massive birthday party for London-based House of Loveness hero Susie Sourwine who gifted her annual birthday party to the HoL children. For many of the children, it was their first time to make a wish and blow out the candles on a birthday cake.
The funds raised from the Share Your Heart campaign will go towards private school fees and school supplies for the children. Any additional funds raised from this campaign will go towards to continued support of the school HoL sponsors in Zimbabwe.


Other Ways You Can Help: $10 to Share Your Heart
Please share the IndieGoGo link with your co-workers, school friends, scout troops, Facebook and Twitter followers. We love the idea of one thousand people giving $10 donations each.
And please post your photo on our Facebook page of you Sharing Your Heart for House of Loveness. It's easy: Draw a heart on your hand and take a photo and then post to Facebook or Twitter.
Share Your Heart because you believe in the future of the children of Zimbabwe. 
With gratitude and love from Zimbabwe,
House of Loveness
Special thanks to Carole Dean and From The Heart Productions for being the fiscal sponsor of House of Loveness. Your donations to this campaign are tax-deductible (please consult your tax advisor)

story:
A Brief Introduction.

My name is Brittany. I am completely independent and have been since 17. I am a part-time student at Houston Community College, which I pay for out of pocket. I volunteer often, I'm active in my community, and I have four jobs. Yes, I said FOUR. However, between rent, bills, classes, and books, I cannot find it in my budget to pay this dental bill. I need help!

What's Up.

My wisdom teeth need to be extracted! I have headaches and migraines constantly. Unfortunately, I also have several cavities that need to be taken care of. It will cost me about $1400 for those, about $600 for my wisdom teeth, and a couple days from work. 

How You Can Make A Difference

Any contributions to my campaign would be greatly appreciated; big or small! Every bit counts. Each $300 is a tooth, and a step towards the first painless day I've had in months! Even a dollar can tip the scales.

Can't spare a dollar? That's okay! You can still help my cause by sharing it with your friends. Social media is an amazing tool, and each set of eyes I can reach is another opportunity to reach my goal!

The Perks

As a thank you for those who are kind enough to donate, I will hand make some cute goodies! Each one will be made with all of my love!


**Please note: Any and all additional funds raised will go towards braces!
