story:
The Project

In the wake of the November 2013 Typhoon Haiyan that ravaged the Philippines, significant need arose for relief. As Christians, we want to be the hands and feet to support our brothers and sister in the Philippines in this time of need. We want to help the community rebuild by supporting them both physically and spiritually.

  

Firsthand view of the results of Typhoon Yolanda, 7 Months After

Who are we? New Life Ministries is a non-profit, Bible printing ministry based in Japan with a 60 year history of sending Bibles and gospel literature around the world. We intend to print and send Bibles and Gospel literature to Tacloban, Philippines for a 10-week Discipleship Program through 30 local churches. This will be accompanied by a Feeding Program. Both programs will focus on relief for children and the strengthening of the community as a whole.

Timeline: October - December 2014

We are very thankful for the program endorsements of the Mayor and Vice Mayor of Tacloban City as well as the Deputy Chief of Mission of the Philippine Embassy in Tokyo.

Mayor Alfred Romualdez with the New Life Team

Deputy Chief of Mission Gilberto Asuque with New Life Members

What We Need & What You Get

We have the skills and means to print on a massive scale. However, we need funding for printing and binding costs as well as funding for the Feeding Program that will be coordinated locally with partners in Tacloban.

Those who contribute will get one of any number of perks listed here.

    The Impact

    Churches in Tacloban lost so much in the disaster. Not only buildings, but even their Bibles and teaching materials. Anyone who has worked with children knows the difficulties of teaching them without visual aids and physically available materials. 

    Providing these materials will:

    1) Strengthen the local churches, helping them to recover and effectively reach out to their communities. One church partner has hundreds of new neighbors now that temporary housing has sprung up literally right next door. This is an opportunity for them to plant hope into the lives of people who have lost everything, as they themselves also work to rebuild. 

    2) Feed the children. Compared to other nations, the Philippines will take more time to recover. Economic levels are much lower. Add a disaster to that, and it becomes even more difficult to make ends meet. For children to have a nutritious meal one time a week and be educated on the Bible, this is tremendously helpful for the family, and the parents can have a break and/or have an opportunity to look for work, even if it is just for a short period of time. 

    We have already laid groundwork by establishing relationships with churches in the region and giving them a sampling of the program materials.

          

    Kids enjoying the manga books in three different churches

      Risks & Challenges

      We have been blessed to have local partners who are working in cooperation with our ministry to make this project work. We are more than capable of printing the books. The biggest challenge now is simply raising the funds.

        Other Ways You Can Help

        Please 'Like' our project on Facebook (www.facebook.com/hopeforlivingphilippines) and spread the word to your friends about this project.

story:
Summary

Blessed Love Good People.

Your girl has been accepted to Film School!! (so maybe I'm not your girl YET but I will be by the end of this video and process :-) its all love!). Anyway, D Rasta needs your help! 

I am Jovander Pacheco from the sweet twin caribbean island of Trinidad and Tobago! Where I come from is so full of vibes, colour, good energy and culture and I have grown quite passionate about depicting culture and people visually - through movies to get us all to feel this oneness! I believe that if I am able to study and become equipped with the tools to creatively and precisely tell these stories and experience new people, places and culture I am one step closer to bringing us all together!

Sadly though in my country we lack some of the resources necessary to provide proper education and training in this field. Also, we are unable to provide the courses necessary to cover the full film scope and specific majors/minors at the moment. 

Fortunately though, I have been accepted to International Film School Syndey and  all I need to get there is YOUR HELP! So please check out these links which provide added information on me, the school and HOW TO DONATE AND SUPPORT! 

Online Presentation

PREZI: http://prezi.com/gpjjximtub2n/?utm_campaign=sha... (this slide show provides more details into my reasons and requests. Please check it out!)

International Film School Sydney: http://ifss.edu.au/

PROGRAM: http://ifss.edu.au/courses/cinematography-advan...

Much Love and Appreciation! #LoveIsTheAnswer #AcceptedToFilmSchool


What I Need & What You Get

Here is a pie chart representation of cost breakdown. 

 Full Cost Break Down Table

DONATIONS:

Please donate by clicking CONTRIBUTE at the top or gp directly to my PayPal: https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_dona...

PayPal email: jovanderpacheco@gmail.com

TRINBAGONIANS please donate locally at - 940554259432 - Republic Bank


PERKS.

1. Mailing List - All doners will be added to a mailing list, through which you will receive  information on updates about school and everything both myself and SelfMade Studios are doing and apart of. 

2. Tee-Shirts - I am currently working on two logos to get some tees printed and if all goes well I will be offering this to donors who donate a certain amount or higher. Will keep you posted!! The tees will be either black or white. 

Take a peek at one of the logos - "The SelfMade Studios LION"


3. Corporate Donors - all corporate donors of TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO, I would like to offer a one-day production on my return from Film School. 

** - Apologies that there aren't more perks involved.. I would give you guys everything if I had it. However, if anything else materialises I will be sure to add it on. :-) 


Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you guys for taking the time to watch the video, read this campaign, and support! Hope you guys enjoyed and at least got to smile! If you have any information on possible scholarships, grants, sponsors, means of funding outside of this, please put in a good word and point me in the direction! Also just the support of you putting that positive energy out there on my behalf is a blessing :)

AND SHARE SHARE SHARE!!! MUCH APPRECIATED. BLESS!!!

story:
WE DID IT! Thank you so much to every person who donated and forwarded my campaign information.  This truly enables me to achieve my dreams for my education and career while continuing to support my family.  I would not be able to do this without everyone's encouragement and help.  I am humbled and deeply moved by your generosity. Thank you, thank you, thank you. Your perks will be coming to you this fall and winter!





me

¡Hola!

  My name is Laura and I am a senior at the University at Albany working towards a double major in Urban Studies & Planning and Globalization with a minor in Spanish.  I have an opportunity to study abroad in Santiago, Chile during my fall semester at ECELA (Español y Cultura en Latino America) Spanish Language School. I will be in Chile from August 17th- December 5th, 2014.  Please help me make this amazing opportunity happen! I receive grants that will cover the full coast of tuition and housing abroad. I need to raise money for my airplane ticket, textbooks, meals, and to help my family with living expenses while I am away and unable to generate income.  In total I need to raise $5,000. We have a stretch goal of $6,000 for the unforeseen living expenses that are sure to arrive.  

  Studying in Chile has been a long time goal of mine.  If I do not take advantage of the funding I have now, I may never be able to go.  Your support is vital in helping me actualize my dreams for my family, education, and career.


Santiago, Chile - Photography by Morten Andersen

Why Santiago, Chile?

  Studying and living in Santiago will undoubtedly enhance my education as an urban planner in a way that is impossible to get by only studying on my home campus. 

  During the last half-century cities in the United States experienced a steady population decline.  This is not the case for the majority of the countries in the world, which are undergoing rapid rates of urbanization and growth.  The metropolitan area of Santiago is home to over 6 million people and is the third largest city in South America. Its rapid growth has presented Chile with urban planning challenges that have created opportunities for innovation and creativity. Experiencing Santiago will expose me to new urban planning strategies I can bring home with me. Practicing urban planning or understanding globalization requires a robust understanding of Latin America; this is something I hope to set a foundation in by studying in Chile.

  To anchor my education I have committed to learning Spanish. I recently received two A’s by completing an intensive 3 week class in Puerto Rico. I have also successfully completed a year of Spanish classes at my home university. However to become fully fluent I need a longer emersion experience.  In Chile, I will be living with a host family and communicating in Spanish every waking hour of the day.  I will complete 4 formal Spanish classes (15 credits).

  Finally learning Spanish is very important to my family, outside of any career or educational goals I might have.  My spouse and children are Puerto Rican and our children have repeatedly asked for help in learning Spanish.  They have visited Puerto Rico and have dreams of going to school there.  My partner can speak Spanish, but increasing family members who are fluent would help our children immensely. 

The kids and I the year we first went to PR

Risks & Challenges

  My path in higher education has been non-traditional.  I am a thirty year old undergraduate student helping to raise two kids. My journey in undergraduate education has been a windy road, eight years in the making. I have remained dedicated and now I am very close to graduating. When college students study abroad they typically are able to put their belongings in storage and just go.  For me it requires not just raising funds for a plane ticket and food, but helping my incredibly supportive and loving family while I am gone.  I will be unable to work at my current job as a secretary and my spouse will still need to pay rent, pay bills, and take care of the kids.  Life will not be put on hold till I come back.

  That said, given that I have my tuition covered, and a host family able to house me, this will be the least expensive opportunity to study abroad and live in a foreign country that I will ever have. I am a senior this year. If I do not go now, I may never be able to go. This is why my family and I have decided that despite the challenges and difficulty in being apart, now is the perfect time. It’s literally now or never!


What we need

Round trip airfare

 $1,400.00

Meals

 $1,200.00

Text Books

   $ 200.00

Living expenses for my family

 $2,200.00


What you get

  This is the fun part! For making my wildest dreams come true I would love to give you a symbol of my heartfelt appreciation. On the right hand side please see the list of "perks" you can get for a donation. When you donate, you will have a chance to choose a donation amount and correlating perk. Feel free to drop me an email or note if you have a specific request or question.

Examples of potential perks!

Some of the perks are:

·  My sincerest gratitude and a shout out on Facebook!

·  Postcard from Santiago Chile!

·  Snail mail letter from me!

·  A bottle of pebre (Chilean hot sauce)!

·  Santiago souvenir!

·  Chilean craft!

·  One hour Spanish lesson!

·  Bottle of Chilean wine!

·  Pie!

·  One time activist task!

·  Help with event planning!

·  Homemade dinner, meal prepared by Chef Victorio!

·  Ten hours of manual labor!


Silly faces

Other ways you can help

  Whether you can donate or not, you can help me achieve this dream by also forwarding my campaign. Please tell everyone you know!  There is a url above you can post on Facebook, e-mail, Twitter, and Tumblr.

  Finally. When I am in Chile please keep Victorio in your hearts.  If nothing else, you would have my eternal gratitude if you offered a few hours of childcare to him while I am gone.

From the bottom of my family’s heart, thank you so much for all your support!

Thank you!

Thank you, thank you, thank you. Your perks will be coming to you this fall and winter!me

story:
The Story...

This summer, I travelled with a group of students to the rural village of Anloga, Ghana and helped teach at the Hafiakor Basic School. As a part of my service there, my team and I helped make sand bricks to construct a library for the school. There was a large stack of bricks that had been piling up for years, but no action had been taken to start constructing the building due to lack of funds. Your donation will go directly to the construction of this library, and help further the educational opportunities of these students for years to come.

Here is an image of the school courtyard (you can see the pile of bricks for the library!)

A typical classroom at the school.


Our Goal

To build this library, the PTA of the school has broken down the specific costs of construction, adding up to be about $2000. The fundraising of this money was broken up between me and another student, and my goal is to raise $1000 for the library. Every penny of the money raised goes directly to the school.

This sum of money will cover all aspects of the construction, including a roof and a paint job. 


Why So Soon?

My goal is to have this money into the hands of the PTA by mid-October. If these funds aren't in soon, the stamina behind the construction will get slower and slower, and the project may stop altogether due to lack of funds. Every penny counts towards making this library a reality for these students!


What You Get

In return for your generous donations, I've made some craft items including postcard sets, handmade heating packs/eye pillows with Ghanaian batik fabric, and candles that will bring you a little piece of Ghana. Check them out!

A few quote candle holders...

A handsewn heating pack....

The growing selection of card sets, handmade with a variety of the images below:


U.S. shipping addresses only, please!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't give today, please share this page any way you can.

Also, if you're interested in donating/buying craft items in person, email me at mari.odoy@gmail.com to see which craft markets I'll be selling at to benefit the library.

The growing selection of card sets, handmade with a variety of the images below:



U.S. shipping addresses only, please!

Other Ways You Can Help If you can't give today, please share this page any way you can.
Also, if you're interested in donating/buying craft items in person, email me at mari.odoy@gmail.com to see which craft markets I'll be selling at to benefit the library.

story:
HELLO

This campaign is about Rose, Faith and Blessing, three girls who have gained admission to higher institutions in Nigeria but would be unable to go to school without financial help. Their faces are different but they share a common story. All three of them have finished secondary school at least two years ago but due to financial constraints, they have been unable to move on to a higher education. Rose’s father suffers from partial paralysis and the family has had to depend on the meager earnings from her mother’s petty trading for survival. Faith comes from a family of peasant farmers whose harvests are dedicated primarily to feeding the family and Blessing had to run away from an option of early marriage offered by the family in the absence of resources to go to school. 

These are three girls with the desperate desire against all odds to have an education capable of liberating them from their present poverty traps and that is why this campaign was set up. Our goal is to raise $6800 which is the estimate required for the three girls to go through two years of school. I know how hard Rose, Blessing and Faith and their families fight to overcome the basic task of daily survival. A higher education will greatly improve their chances of breaking this vicious cycle of poverty. This is why we need your help so these girls would not have to bring the unfortunate circumstances of their present into their future.

Rose, Faith and Blessing may not be the girl next door. In fact, to you, they are probably total strangers in a distant corner of the world. But in the end they are 3 human beings… individuals like you with dreams and aspirations and desperate to achieve them. Wherever we are from, we are all connected by our humanity. I truly believe that by virtue of this connection, you can lend a hand to help these girls achieve their simple dreams. Unless you have been there, you truly cannot imagine how much your generous donations will transform their lives. We need your help.

THEIR STORIES

 
Roseline Yusuf is the 4th child in a family of 5 children ( 7 in total) , a family in a dire financial situation that threatens to deny her a simple dream of an education. Rose is 19 and finished high school 2 years ago but had to wait until now to gain an admission to study Computer Science at Federal Polytechnic Idah, Nigeria. Rose needs help to afford school. For the last few years, her dad has been unable to work due to partial paralysis, and with a mother engaged in petty trading, the meagre family resources have been dedicated to the uphill task of daily survival. Rose is due to resume school by the end of February and an estimated cost of $2075 is what she needs to complete a 2-year National Diploma. Rose needs our help to achieve a simple dream. Will you help her?

Faith Aver Toryila is 19 and has just been offered admission to study Social and Environmental Forestry at the Federal University of Agriculture, Makurdi, Nigeria. Without financial assistance, she is going to have to forfeit the admission, and sadly, this would not be the first time. Three years after completing her secondary school education, she is still unable to go on and study for a higher degree. At the moment, there are musings within her family to get her married  in order to cushion her family's economic challenges. This may be her fate if she does not get financial assistance. Together, we can help avert that fate. Her programme is a 5-year degree; this campaign aims to help her through the first two years. An estimated $2054 is what stands between Faith and this goal. Kindly lend a hand.

Blessing Godday is 19 and has also had to forfeit admission due to lack of financial support. This year she gained admission again to study Laboratory Science Technology and I started a campaign on Facebook on December 5, 2014 to raise money for her. The campaign generated $476 with which she has paid her fees and obtain accommodation. Blessing still needs help for books, transportation and feeding. This campaign aims to raise enough funds for the duration of her 2-year National Diploma. The estimate to reach this goal is $1610. Kindly help Blessing to finish the programme she has started. 
OUR NEED

The objective of the campaign is to raise enough money to finance two years of tertiary education for each of the girls. For Blessing and Roseline that would be enough to earn a National Diploma, however Faith would have 3 more years to earn her degree. The estimates used here involve fees, accommodation, living expenses (basically feeding) and miscellaneous (books, internet, transportation, printing, etc.) needed per year and then upscaled to cover 2 years for each of them.

Roseline:

Fees - $227, Accommodation - $ 216.20, Living Expenses – $432.40, Miscellaneous - $162.20

Total per year = $1037.80, Total for TWO YEARS = $2075.60

Faith:

Fees - $216.20, Accommodation - $ 216.20, Living Expenses – $432.40, Miscellaneous - $162.20

Total per year = $1027, Total for TWO YEARS = $2054

Blessing:

Fees - $232.40, Accommodation - $ 189.20, Living Expenses – $432.40, Miscellaneous - $162.20

Total for first year (fees and accommodation already paid from Facebook fundraising, hence only living expenses and miscellaneous needed) = $594.60

Total for second year = $1015, Total for TWO YEARS = $1610

Total for 3 Girls = $5739

Amount required to meet above total = $6308 (Since 9% of funds go to the website). We are also allowing $500 for buying and delivering perks, hence:

Campaign Target = $6800

PLAN OF ACTION

Roseline is due to resume school late March and Faith resumes early April. Blessing is already in school and only needs funds for living expenses for the rest of the session.

  • Campaign Target:  $6800
  • Campaign Duration:  26th January 2015 – 6th March 2015 (40 days)
  • A trust fund would be set up with a bank under the Develop a Youth (DAY) foundation which would be registered in Nigeria this January.
  • Between late March and early April realized funds would be disbursed  to pay for fees and housing for first year and living expenses for the first semester (4 months)
  • Funds would be deposited into Trust Fund bank account and instructions left with the bank to disburse funds to the beneficiaries' accounts subsequently as follows:
  • Fees and accommodation for the session, at the beginning of each session
  • Living expenses per month at the beginning of every month from the second semester for 2 years
  • If the funds raised do not meet the target of the campaign; priority will be given to the tuition fees and accommodation fees.
  • Once tuition and accommodation have been paid for,the remaining funds will be  evenly distributed and paid to the beneficiaries during the target duration of the assistance (two years).
  • If the funds raised are more than the target amount; the excess would be used to pay for the beneficiaries’ studies beyond the first two years of their studies as planned.
  • The Develop a Youth Foundation would also find scholarship resources which the girls will be eligible for upon resumption of school and help them access such funds.

WHAT YOU WILL HELP US ACHIEVE

Poverty continues to stand as one of the principal hindrances to the enrollment of girls in tertiary education throughout the developing world. Roseline, Faith and Blessing have shown a strong desire for higher education but are unfortunately caught in a poverty trap. Your contribution to this campaign, will make a huge impact upon the lives of these 3 girls . 

In a Nigerian economy with high unemployment and stiff competition for jobs, without higher education these girls do not stand a chance at leading a better life and breaking this  vicious cycle of poverty, with repercussions even for their unborn children. By contributing to this initiative, you are providing a potential gateway to poverty reduction and the achievement of sustainable development on a personal level for the girls and Nigeria in general.

Women are, by default in Nigeria, disadvantaged with respect to economic and socio-political empowerment. A higher education will provide these girls the tools needed for independence, save them from potentially looming early marriages that would only further their cycle of poverty. On a larger scale , with a higher education they will be better equipped to contributing towards the overall development of Nigeria and by extension to global development.

Nigeria still has one of the worst maternal and child mortality rates in the world. Harmful cultural practices like disinheritance and female genital mutilation are some of the unfortunate things women still suffer. Without a doubt, women who are educated and economically empowered are less likely to suffer these unfortunate situations. By contributing to this campaign, you would be empowering women educationally, and consequently economically and politically.

Of particular importance is the opportunity for these girls to access all levels of education in order to take advantage of the growing opportunities in Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics (STEM)  and  related areas. Being underrepresented in these fields of study, your help will therefore propel these girls to go beyond their "expected" boundaries.

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

We would be grateful if you could help us by sharing our campaign among your friends through email or your Facebook , Instagram and Twitter profiles and encouraging them to make a donation. You can also make book donations in the fields of Laboratory Science and Technology, Computer Science and Social/Environmental Forestry.

Many thanks for your contribution and for changing a life!

WE, The Team

Hello. My name is Itodo Anthony. I hold an MSc from Heriot-Watt University, Edinburgh, Scotland. I also belong to Junior Chamber International, an organization for young people where we believe that service to humanity is the best work of life. I have always volunteered service to create positive change.  In Edinburgh, I worked as a volunteer with the just Festival. I also volunteered with the Health and Opportunities Team, where I worked with young boys to improve their sense of self-esteem and confidence. Recently I initiated a programme to provide in-house education for juvenile inmates in a remand home in Nigeria. I am on this campaign because I know first hand the kind of difficult future that awaits these girls without higher education in Nigeria.  Join us to make this a success.

Hi, my name is Samantha-Kaye Christie and I hail from the beautiful parish of Hanover in Jamaica. I hold a M.A in Education from the Liverpool Hope University and one of my goals is to make an invaluable contribution to human development through education. My project management portfolio includes Project Manager for "Jamaica, Our Island Treasure" at Junior Chamber International, which assisted Grade 6 students to prepare for their upcoming examinations,External Affairs Chairperson during my undergraduate years, co-coordinator for the Rex Nettleford Hall Summer Camp , Project Manager for The Read to Lead Initiative at the Jamaica Christian Boys Home and Reading Support Organizer at St Annes Primary School in Liverpool. I believe it is  noble  to assist young people to achieve their dreams, regardless of their country of origin. Join our team and become a global change-maker by  promoting goodwill among all cultures.

My LinkedIn Profile :

https://uk.linkedin.com/pub/samantha-kaye-d-chr...


Hello everyone. I am Riten Chand Gosai, currently a MSc. - Tropical Plant Pathology student at the University of Hawaii in USA. Originally from the rural interiors of the small Pacific nation Fiji, perhaps I understand most what humble beginnings are. I am forever grateful for the scholarships I received to further my education, however, not everyone is fortunate to come by these opportunities. The struggle, the plight is real! And blessed are those hands which help elevate - across borders, without prejudice. The thread that binds us all into one is the quintessence of Humanity - the very reason I joined hands with my friends from Africa and the Caribbean. It may seem as little as just another 3 girls attaining tertiary education, but for them it's as big as dreams come true; as real as an escape from poverty and as divine as blessings from up above. I know you will hold hands with us. Thank you for your contribution.

Previous fundraiser:

http://www.fijisun.com.fj/2013/06/14/mulomulo-soccer-team-gets-help/
http://www.sportsone.ca/fiji-sports/46-soccer/1086-asuad-ali.html
https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.610116102346841.1073741826.199364980088624&type=1
My website:
http://gosai8.wix.com/mycv

Hi, my name is Freeman Dugguh, from Benue state, Nigeria. I hold an MSc is Subsea Engineering from Cranfield University, Bedfordshire, England. I am the author of "Obeying the Clarion Call", a book on personal development for youth in Nigeria. I worked as a volunteer with Family and Community Life Reorientation, a millennium development goals group at the National Youth Service Corps in Nigeria, for a period of 12 months. Everyone deserves a fair shot at a successful life and sometimes it takes people like you and me to give someone that fair chance. Please join us in giving these girls a fair chance.

story:
About Myself:

      My name is Grace Sampson and I am from Chicago, Illinois. I am  18, a senior in high-school and am excited to be graduating very soon. This year I have struggled with the question, "What college are you going to and what are you majoring in?" Most of my friends already knew where they wanted to go and what they wanted to do but I was clueless, until I discovered the program Thinking Beyond Borders. Ever since I found out what this was all about I was one hundred percent sure this is what I wanted to do this upcoming fall. I know that this will point me in just the right direction for my future which is why it is very important to me. This September I will be traveling with a small group to Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia, and Washington, D.C.. We will be living with host families, studying, and language learning. We will be doing field work with local experts and addressing global issues, getting a better understanding of the world. Read below to learn more about what we will specifically be doing.

 First Stop Ecuador – Education in the Coastal Low-Lands

Education is the keystone of development. It can empower individuals and communities to improve health and create equity and justice. We will investigate how governments, non-profits, and independent actors work to address the needs of a rural community. Our group will work in public and private schools to understand education in Ecuador. 

Peru – Trek to Machu Picchu

We will travel to Peru and hike the Inca Trail to Machu Picchu. Throughout the four-day trek, our guide will describe the Incan Empire and its mysteries as we hike through many Incan ruins before coming to the awe-inspiring sunrise view of Machu Picchu.

Bolivia – Sustainable Agriculture in the High Valleys

Over the past 60 years, the world’s population has tripled as we have developed ways to dramatically increase agricultural production. Farmers use technology to increase crop yields, but these often bring pollution, impoverish small farmers, and threaten food safety. We will live with families in the town of Cochabamba and experience first-hand the innovative ways in which urban communities are tackling food insecurity. We will investigate how farmers, government, and businesses cooperate to balance demand for food with the ecosystem in Bolivia.

Washington, D.C.

Then we will explore the relationship between the US and the rest of the world. We will meet representatives from the World Bank, Congress, and NGOs to discuss international development. We will reflect to bring together our learning and experiences into powerful conclusions in a final project to raise awareness about critical global issues. 

Tuition

The only thing standing in my way is the cost. Unfortunately this all does come with a price. This wonderful trip is $12,000 and don't forget about airfare. This is why I really do need your help. Any donation is greatly appreciated and will go to me for only the expense of my trip. With your donation I can send you emails updating you on the trip, I can send post cards, or even small gifts.. you name it! No donation is too small!

What Your Contributions Will Support:

  • Hands-on service work with those who face issues on a daily basis.
  • Putting me in the right direction for when I attend college. 
  • Preparing me to offer more informed solutions to important global issues.
  • To help further my education, learning about critical problems.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you just can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help! It would be awesome if you could get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. All you need to do is use the Indiegogo share tools.

Thank you very much!

story:
We have a vision:  an herbalist in every community, able to provide skilled, sensitive, accessible holistic health care, using nature's gifts as their tools and nature's wisdom as their guide.  Everyone should have an herbalist to turn to.  Herbalists go to the root causes of disease instead of just managing symptoms.  They empower people to take control of their own health, relying on plants from the garden and the wild lands nearby, and on simple practices that you can do at home.  If everyone knew an herbalist, no one would have to solely rely on our expensive, unjust, and inadequate medical system.

The Terra Sylva School trains exactly this kind of community herbalist in our unique full-immersion summer internship program (read on for why our program and our location is so special).  But we have outgrown our facilities, so this year we’re building a new facility that will house an indoor classroom, our extensive research library, our herbal apothecary, and an attached greenhouse for growing medicinal herbs. 

We have our design ready, we have labor lined up, our neighbor’s sawmill is ready to provide the lumber.  We’re asking you to help with the cost of materials.


Our Work

Medicine County Herbs is an herbal apothecary & medicinal plant nursery located off the grid high in an Appalachian cove forest near Asheville, North Carolina.  Our herbal practice was born of full-time immersion in this forest, the richest ecosystem in Appalachia.  We share this immersive experience with our students each summer in our residential apprenticeship program, the Terra Sylva School.

An herbal education does more than inform an individual student—its impact reverberates as students share their healing knowledge with friends, family, and community.  At our school, we seek to sow the seeds of generations of community herbalists by providing an inclusive and safer space for passionate students of all genders, races, ethnicities, and economic backgrounds.  We differ from other herb schools in that we provide an education in radical, DIY, community-minded herbalism in a rural setting.

At our school, we avoid gender essentialism, and teach clinical skills for working with transgender and gender nonconforming clients.  We acknowledge the debt that North American herbalism owes to Native people without fetishizing Native culture.  We teach trauma-informed care, and give our students the skills to create affordable and culturally sensitive protocols.

Students live on our farm through the summer and trade work around the land, in our gardens, and in our apothecary for a comprehensive course in herbal medicine.  We charge no tuition for this education.


Our Farm

Our school, gardens, nursery, and apothecary are located on 40 acres in a rural mountain cove in Madison County, North Carolina.  We started from scratch on this undeveloped land in 2001 and have added to it little-by-little, working with limited resources.  By now it features a number of small houses built with natural building methods (clay, straw, sand, poles harvested from our land), a large communal kitchen, several permaculture gardens watered by year-round springs, a solar-powered electrical system, a stage for performances, and even an elaborate treehouse.

Our neighborhood is made up of old-school Appalachian mountain folks, who’ve lived here for many generations.  Herbal medicine was still practiced as primary care when some of them were children, but is now a dying tradition.  Still, they mostly avoid doctors, and they're pleased to have herbalists in the neighborhood again, even if we don’t practice quite like Granny did!


Who We Are and What We Stand For

We are Dave Meesters and Janet Kent, two practicing herbalists who are as passionate about plants as we are about health care.  Dave has been practicing herbalism for 12 years.  He organized and staffed an herbal free clinic in a New Orleans neighborhood devastated by hurricane Katrina, and, as part of the Sassafras Community Health Collective, organized and worked at a free clinic in Asheville’s homeless shelter.  Janet is a specialist in mental health support, and is the author of the popular booklet Ease Your Mind: Herbs for Mental Health.  On top of seeing clients, maintaining a nursery, an apothecary, and running an herb school, we also teach around the country and in nearby Asheville, and share herbal info and experiences on Facebook, Instagram, and on our blog.

For us, herbalism is not only a more appropriate, accessible, effective, and pleasurable form of health care than the dominant system, it is a also a vital way to re-forge humanity’s severed bond with nature—which is a healing act unto itself.  Our mission includes bringing competent holistic herbal care and herbal medicine to people who cannot afford upscale ‘alternative’ modalities, and teaching new herbalists to do the same. Our school is designed to extend education in herbal medicine to students who share these values and might not be able to afford the cost of other herb schools.  Gardening is an integral aspect of our herbal practice and philosophy:  we distribute live medicinal plants through our nursery and encourage everyone to grow their own medicine.

You can read more about us, our school, read our blog, and see more photos at www.medicinecountyherbs.com.


Our Current Project: A New Classroom and Apothecary!

We are currently raising funds for the construction of our new classroom, library, and apothecary.  Our school has become popular in the years since we began, and every year we have to turn away more applicants because our facilities cannot accommodate more than a handful of students.  Also, the lecture classes are held in our lovely but open-to-the-elements communal kitchen & dining space, and we are much in need of a dedicated, sheltered classroom that can be used in all weather.  Our improved classroom would also enable us to host intensives and workshops by visiting teachers.

The new classroom will double as a library for students and community, with an emphasis on herbs, holistic health, gardening, and permaculture.  As we have varied interests and decades of book collecting behind us, the library will also house books on all kinds of topics, including many books not found in conventional libraries, from radical anthropology to alchemical manuscripts to rare Dada, Surrealism, and the utopian writings of Charles Fourier.

Also, our herbal apothecary has grown as we have added more remedies and dispense more and more medicine to those in need.  Right now we house our apothecary in a corner of our small (400 square foot) house; it shares the kitchen with daily food prep and cooking.  The new building will include an expanded apothecary with a dedicated medicine-making kitchen, accessible to students and community members.


Next year we will attach a large greenhouse that will provide passive-solar heating for the classroom/library, and allow us to expand our nursery by starting many more medicinal plants from seeds and cuttings.


Why We Are Reaching Out

In everything that we offer to the world, whether it’s giving health advice, dispensing herbal medicine, distributing medicinal plants, or teaching budding herbalists, we have chosen to avoid a profit-based model as much as we can.  Our work is a labor of love and of ardent commitment to our values.  Being affordable (or free), accessible, and inclusive does not guarantee there will be extra money to expand the project.

It is because our herbalism serves and supports the greater community that we are seeking community support to expand what we can do.


How We’re Going to Build It

In the fifteen years since we started on this land, we’ve acquired plenty of building experience by designing and constructing our own houses and community infrastructure.  We have an exciting design for the building, illustrated in this amateur “artist’s rendering” by Dave:

Like everything else on the farm, we’re going to build it ourselves, with the help of our summer apprentices (who will get a thorough education in house carpentry along the way) and visiting friends who are experienced builders and have volunteered their time.  This means that there will be no labor costs.

We’re also using trees from our own land for as much of the lumber as possible.  We’ve cut a number of Tulip Poplars to clear the building site, and our neighbors are converting them to lumber with their sawmill operation.


How much will it cost to build?

Here is our basic cost estimate for materials:

lumber, poplar
lumber, pine
nails
foundation poles
insulation
metal roofing & screws
subflooring
wall sheathing
interior siding
stairs
house wrap
ceiling
flashing
doors & windows
roof sheathing

Total:
 $1,700
1,100
300
200
900
500
500
400
500
75
150
150
50
225
250

$7,000

(These are conservative cost estimates, and in many cases reflect low-cost used or salvaged materials.)

With the materials above, we could construct a shell of building, 32’ x 18’, 1.5 stories with under-floor storage, insulated and protected from the elements, looking something like this:

This is what we can build for $7,000


After that, the task would be to finish the inside, building bookshelves, furniture, apothecary kitchen and storage, plumbing, electricity, and installing a wood-burning stove for heating.  If we raise more than our goal in this campaign, then we could move on to finishing the inside right away.

Greenhouse construction is not included in the costs above either.  A fully-outfitted greenhouse (28’ x 15’) would cost around $3,000.  Any further funding raised beyond the above would be put toward the greenhouse.

This is what we would build with more!!


Make no mistake, all of this will be built no matter how much money we raise in this campaign.  The success of this campaign will determine whether it is built little-by-little, or quickly so that the new facilities can be ready to use sooner for our expanding school, apothecary, and nursery.


What You Get for Participating

Your foremost reward in supporting our campaign is the satisfaction of acting in solidarity with a project that shares your values:  DIY herbal medicine, holistic healing, grassroots health care, radical herbal education, connection with plants & nature, gardening as a healing practice, permaculture & ecological stewardship.

In addition, you are welcome to choose from our exciting perks!  These include herbal medicine from our apothecary, specialized personal health consultations with herbal support, and class recordings from our Terra Sylva School.

Herbal tincture extracts can be chosen from our catalog.

The Herbal Care Packages to choose from are:

  •   Cold Season:  2 oz. of Immune Boost, 2 oz. of Echinacea, 2 oz. Elderberry Syrup
  •   First Aid:  1 oz. Echinacea tincture, 1 oz. Calendula, 1 oz. Yarrow, 1 oz. Relax, 1 oz. All-Purpose Salve
  •   Mood Support:  2 oz. Heart Heal, 2 oz. Relax, 2 oz. Invincible Summer
For descriptions of the formulas see our catalog.

Click here for a list of class recordings available.

How you can help

You can support this project by becoming a campaign contributor, and by helping spread the word about our project by sending emails or sharing our campaign on social media to people, networks, or forums where our project would be likely to find sympathizers and supporters.  Indiegogo share tools make it easy!

Thank you for supporting our project!

story:
Short Summary

Pathway to Certification is a start up company founded by two Board Certified Behavior Analysts, Erica Bauer and Lisa Nikiforuk. Both Erica and Lisa have worked in the field with children and adults with Autism and their families. They have supervised students on the path to taking the certification exam to become Behavior Analysts.

What motivated us to start this company/website? 

The number of people pursuing certification and becoming BCBA's is growing, as is the need for quality supervision of future practitioners. We believe that educators, families, and businesses in need of behavior analytic services deserve to have well trained, highly prepared Behavior Analysts working with you. 

(BACB.com)

What will your contributions do? 

You will be helping to create a website for supervisors and supervisees to keep track of accrued supervision hours, and mastery of skills required to become exceptional Behavior Analysts.

Why should they need to keep track of their supervision in such a way?

This tool will allow supervisors to monitor their supervisees progress by visually displaying areas of strength and areas for improvement, while also tracking the number of supervision hours they are accruing as required by the board. This will help supervisors navigate their supervision curriculum and provide access to resources, projects and practice opportunities that will help their student focus on the skills they need to improve.

Who are Board Certified Behavior Analysts and what do they do?

A Board Certified Behavior Analyst® (BCBA®) is a behavioral health professional who develops & implements treatment plans towards positive behavioral changes & life skill acquisition.

BCBA’s hold a graduate-level certification in behavior analysis. Professionals who are certified at the BCBA level are independent practitioners who provide behavior-analytic services. In addition, BCBAs supervise the work of Board Certified Assistant Behavior Analysts, Registered Behavior Technicians, and others who implement behavior-analytic interventions (BACB.com).

What We Need & What You Get

Below is a list of developmental steps for our webstite and how much they will cost based on a quote provided by our web developer.

Creating Wireframe - $1500

Use an existing theme, setup pages and add relevant dummy content- $1500

Programming of all functionality - $6000

QA and testing - $500

Communication - $2000

Misc launch things (google analytics, seo review, speed optimisation, check your content for any feedback) - $500

Any funds provided will go directly toward the development of our website!

The Impact

Your contribution will directly impact the proficiency and quality of supervision that is provided to those preparing to take their certification exam. You will be the change that is needed to have well supervised professionals in the field!

Risks & Challenges

The risk with our project is if we are not able to get enough supervising Behavior Analysts to use our site as a tool to better supervise candidates. Being in the field and having social media to aid in advertisement and decemination of this product will allow us to reach as many people as possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share our indiegogo fund me page with others!

story:
The first four Manuals for School Nurses left today via Priority Mail to four schools in Vermont.  This means that four nurses are going to know a whole lot more about ME/CFS than they did yesterday. This is literally where the rubber meets the road. These manuals were sent out directly because of 4 -  $40.00 donations.  
You can make a difference, in your town, in your school, in your state.  
Thank you for your support.

Adopt a School Nurse
In Your Town, In Your School, In Your State
It's Quick, It's Easy. 
Thank you for your support.


There is increasing awareness of ME/CFS in children and adolescents.  It is more common in children over 10 than in younger children, though it can affect children as young as 5. 13% of youth who get Infectious Mononucleosis go on to develop ME/CFS.  This illness commonly persists for many years.  There is no known cure.  Because it is not well known or understood by most doctors, it is thought that over 80% of people with ME/CFS are undiagnosed or misdiagnosed.

We have developed a 98 page manual specifically for school nurses.  The manual will help to identify this serious illness among a student population, and while there is no known cure, we CAN establish a recovery protocol that could prevent a lifetime of disease.

The materials are supplied with permission from the following organizations;

NJCFSA: www.njcfsa.org 
The CFIDS Association of America,  http://www.cfids.org dba:The Solve CFS/ME Initiative
The Organization for Fatigue & Fibromyalgia Education, (OFFER), Utah,http://www.offerutah.org
The International Association of CFS/ME, (IACFS/ME), http://www.iacfsme.org
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, http://www.cdc.gov/cfs
Massachusetts CFIDS/ME & FM Association, http://www.MassCFIDS.org

It is immensely difficult for adults to grasp even a rudimentary knowledge of this disease and a task that is multiplied tenfold when it affects children. We are literally charting new ground and ask for your help.
Please share this with your friends and professional associates.

http://www.immunedysfunction.org/pediatric.html

story:
In December 1997, the winds of Typhoon Paka carried destruction through the Pacific island of Guam.  In the wreckage of their southern home, Don Eckert and his wife Tessie looked up to where their ceiling used to be and were saddened for their now-homeless family. 

 

In the following weeks as he sorted through the damage, Don heard the calling from God to be a preacher.  He felt that his true purpose – a purpose he’d long been running from – finally caught up with him.  Soon he committed himself to “sharing the Gospel to raise up Christ-centered families,” a commitment that would become the mission of Guahan Baptist Church.

 

Don’s home was eventually renovated with a new concrete roof, and the Eckert family moved back into their home in August 2000.  On the road to becoming a preacher, Don led Bible studies in his home and took classes at Harvest Baptist Bible Institute.  After obtaining his bachelor’s degree in Pastoral Ministries in May 2010, Don was ordained at Harvest Baptist Church in January 2011. 

 

In the next few months with the help of Christian brother Sam Pueyo (who has now gone to be with the Lord), Don’s carport was enclosed; and the first service for Guahan Baptist Church was held in May 2011.  There in Ipan Talofofo, a village affectionately proclaimed as “God’s Country” by its residents, God immediately began working in the hearts of the faithful and attendance grew.

The need for a larger building soon became clear.

 

In May 2014, Pastor Don graduated with a Master of Ministry from Northland International University in Wisconsin.  Through a generous agreement in 2015 with Tessie’s parents, Ricardo & Maria Quiambao, land was leased for a future church building only a short distance away from Guahan Baptist Church’s current location.

 

The planning and permitting began and was completed in September 2016.  In the months ahead, a steel-framed building will go up, along with leaching field, septic tank, and restroom facilities.  The spacious lot will include ample parking and an area for a small kitchen and church activities. 

 

We are asking for people to partner with us as we build our new church to expand God’s kingdom.  Here are three ways you can help:

Prayer – Hardly a great thing is accomplished without the bending of the knees and hearts to God. We ask that you join us in prayer knowing that “if we ask anything according to His will, He hears us.”  

Time/Expertise – God has blessed us all with unique skills and talents. Every hammer swing and every stroke of the paintbrush brings us closer to worshipping in our new building.  Being available for even the smallest tasks would be a tremendous help and a blessing. 

Finances – The construction of the building, along with the installation of audio-visual systems and seating, will result in an overall cost that isn’t small.  We know God will provide, and there is nothing too hard for Him.  If God has put you in a position to give financially, please pray and consider giving towards the project.  

 

We thank you for your kind consideration, and we pray that God will lay it on your heart to participate in any of these three areas.  Any way you contribute will support the greater mission of sharing the Gospel with those who don’t know Christ on our island of Guam.

story:
We are Social Digital 18, a group of Product and Digital Interaction designers who will soon graduate from the University of Dundee. Over the past year we have been working hard on our honours projects, creating a range of products and services which aim to improve people’s lives or draw attention to important social issues. We intend to display this work at two events: our Degree show in Dundee in May and at New Designers in London in July. To this end we need the materials and funding to make both of these events happen and this is where we ask for your help.

Your contributions to our campaign will provide us with the resources necessary to exhibit our work and the means to transport us down to London for New Designers. In doing so you would provide us with the opportunity to display our work to the public and potentially advance our careers as designers.

Any contribution you can make would be greatly appreciated by all of us and we hope to see you at our degree show!

story:
Hi everybody,

my name is Marco Ricci and I am a 37-year-old art historian with Austrian and Italian family background. I live in Vienna and have always been interested in genetics, genealogy and the migration patterns of ancient tribes and peoples. When I was a child I fantasized that one day it would be possible to tell from your DNA who your ancestors were. Nowadays we live that childhood fantasy of mine! People from all over the world learn that their lineages are connected and help us to develop a feeling of global culture awareness!

Two years ago I learned about the possibilities of genetic genealogy and had my own Y-DNA tested. The resolution of the initial test was very small as I only could afford a 12-marker test. When I received my results I was nevertheless astonished. I turned out to be Y-DNA haplogroup J1! From my experience every European has that WOW! feeling once he discovers to belong to J1 as this is a quite rare haplogroup in Europe but very common in the Middle East. From that very moment I wanted to know more about my male ancestors and their ethnic background. After a Deep Clade test I was sure to belong to a big cluster that is present in Arab as well as in Jewish and other Middle Eastern populations. This cluster is called J-L147.1. My curiosity grew stronger and stronger!

The more SNPs I tested the more I was fascinated by this group as my sample tested negative for all subclade-defining SNPs downstream from L147.1 except L858! I began to read internet forums, scientific studies and post here and there and eventually became volunteer project co-admin of the FTDNA KMY and Y-DNA Haplogroup J Project. My enthusiasm has not diminished since then but is steadily growing because of the innovations genetic genealogy is undergoing! A big step in the last years is the possibility to have your complete Y-DNA (and not only single markers) sequenced and that is this project’s goal: raise the additional 1100$ that are still necessary to make this happen!

What are the benefits for the donors? Once my Y-DNA is sequenced, hundreds of new SNPs will be available for everybody. These single unique mutations will help clarify the phylogeny of my branch of haplogroup J1, namely J-L858! We will try our best and make these SNPs testable to the benefit of every single genetic genealogist. It could help us also understand when our ancestors arrived in Central Europe and which source population they were belonging to in the Middle East. Many fascinating new insights will emerge from this and a great many people will eventually profit from the results! By contributing to this project you help us make this happen! Even a small amount of money is giving us a helping hand and can be decisive in the realization!

Yours,

Marco Ricci

FTDNA Kit# E13058

story:
RUBY CUP: Menstruation Matters

Ruby Cup is a menstrual cup that is re-usable for 10 years. With 400 of your tokens during Socap12, we will make sure that 250 primary schoolgirls in Kenya wont have to worry about their menstruation again until they are done with college. For many of them, this could mean that they will actually make it through school.

IT’S A BLOODY MESS

Menstruation is the main cause of school drop-out for girls in poverty and hinders women in achieving life opportunities. Sanitary pads are too expensive or simply unavailable. Instead, women use mud, bark, rags, cotton wool, pieces of mattress or pieces of newspaper. Unhygienic and undignified solutions. This is 20% of school/work time!

Just think about it, who would want to be seen leaking in public? Menstruation is a taboo, and an overlooked issue effecting more than 1 billion women and girls globally. Let’s help girls and women move beyond the shame.

My name is Veronica D'Souza and I am the co-founder and Managing Director of Ruby Cup. We provide a sustainable solution to menstruation for girls and women in poverty. With 1 Ruby Cup, a girl can go from primary through college with out having to worry about her menstruation.

RUBY CUP: A Sustainable Solution

Ruby Cup is a high quality menstrual cup made of 100% medical grade silicone that is re-usable for 10 years. I personally use Ruby Cup because it is healthier than pads and tampons, cost-saving, safe, and environmentally friendly.

We are selling and distributing Ruby Cup in the slums of Nairobi through female entrepreneurs. This way, we generate income for women, increase peer-to-peer education about menstrual hygiene, and solve the problem sustainably. We also sell Ruby Cup online for a premium price in western markets (in case you want to get one for yourself or your wife) and use this revenue to cross subsidize the cost for women and girls in poverty.

THIS PARTICULAR CAMPAIGN: Schoolgirls in Kenya 

With this campaign, at SOCAP12, you can  change lives for girls immediately.

All money raised through this campaign during SOCAP12, will be used to provide primary schoolgirls in the slums of Nairobi with a Ruby Cup. Each Ruby Cup comes with training and education about reproductive health.

We are a for-profit company, and there is an enormous market worldwide for Ruby Cup.

But there are primary schoolgirls who will never be able to afford our product. Let’s help them today.

THE BIGGER PICTURE 

Our team is ambitious. Since we started one year ago, we have designed and produced our product together with the women and girls in Kenya. We have done acceptability testing and just launched sales in three different slum areas in Nairobi with our first commercial shipment of 10.000 units. We have 500 happy Ruby Cup users in Kenya, Uganda and South Africa in the age of 13 - 35. And we are just getting started.

Our goal is to reach 1 million women and girls world wide over the next 5 years through both a market based distribution model that generates income for women and through donations in cooperation with NGOs and governments.

We cannot do it alone. I am here at Socap12 to meet with you, get connected to relevant partners, and fundraise $500,000 in grants and debt. I will be showcasing Ruby Cup all day Wednesday in the main hall. Write me, meet with me, and come and hear more about Ruby Cup. 

Thank you on behalf of my team and the schoolgirls in Kenya.

Veronica D’Souza

Letter from Annet Shilaho 15 years old, Skt. Jones primary School, Kibera, Nairobi. 

"My first day when I started my menstruation period I used rugs because my father did not afford to buy me a pad. I did not have anyone to afford to buy for me cause my mother had been already dead. I felt ashamed of myself. I stayed for a week at home because I thought it was not normal. I was very funny because I went everywhere telling people that the bleeding is come out of my vagina. A few days later friend introduce me to their life skills teacher. I explained everything to her and at last she promised to provide for me pads. 

My opinion about Rub cup is that it helps me a lot because before I was using two pads per day. I thank Moraa and Ruby Cup because they made my dreams come true. Cause once before she came I was ashamed facing my father asking him to buy me pads. Ruby cup is my number one choice cause it has help me a lot. Since I started used it I have seen changes. It has even help me saving my dad’s money. I don’t have much to say all I ask you all is to bring more ruby cup to help others a lot. The thing is good a lot if even you wear it nobody will notice. 

I prefer Ruby cup than anything else."

TEAM

We are three young female entrepreneurs from Copenhagen Business School (Maxie, Julie and I) who have started Ruby Cup together. We now live in Nairobi where we are working full speed on introducing Ruby Cup in the slums. If you are passing by, we’ll happily invite you for a Bloody Mary.

Ruby Cup is the winner of The Global Social Entrepreneurship Competition 2012 (US), Venture Cup 2012 (DK), a selected Sustainia100 Solution, Finalist in Ben&Jerry's Join Our Core 2012 (EU), Awarded Fidelity Future Impact Award 2nd prize 2012 (CH).

 

CONTACT

Veronica D'Souza: vds@makit.dk

Follow us @ www.ruby-cup.com www.facebook/rubycup www.twitter/rubycup 

"This campaign was designed for the SOCAP conference community for it's annual gathering on October 1-4th.  A group of 100 entrepreneurs selected 5 entrepreneurs to showcase their work through a small crowdfunding campaign on Indiegogo. The entrepreneurs were given 2 hours to develop their campaign page. The campaign will run for 1 week to an audience of 1500 global social innovators at SOCAP.  SOCAP attendees were given a wooden token representative of $5 that they will choose to designate towards 1 of the 5 project, in total worth $10,000.  Additionally, attendees are encouraged to further contribute both financially and otherwise. Though the entrepreneurs have financial goals far exceeding the small amount they will raise through the campaign, this exercise is a symbol of how crowd and community support towards inspiring and innovative individuals can leverage great resources to change the world."

story:
Short Summary

Most of us are thankful that our children not only have their basic needs met but also have opportunities of a lifetime.  However, there are many  children who don't. Pine Grove Elementary is a title 1 school located in Delray Beach, Florida in a community of extremely limited means.  Close to 98% of the students qualify for free or reduced lunches and English is a second language to a majority of these students.  This school has to do food and clothing drives every month just to meet students' basic needs. So you can imagine how hard it is for them to raise money for a basic school trip, let alone meet the $20,000 they need to get to D.C.   These 5th graders NEED YOUR HELP!  Your donation will help them go to Washington D.C. for the first time in 5 years!

  • My name is Janen Moyer-Pesso and I'm a parent at a sister school, Addison Mizner Elementary, in Boca Raton, FL.  I was touched by these students and their story and am determined to get them to D.C.  Won't you help?
  • This campaign is important to me because I believe in "paying it forward".  My family and the students at our school are fortunate enough to experience these trips and many others every year.  I want to help give these children a once-in-a lifetime experience that will inspire them to work hard to lead a successful life.
  • Your contribution will help these 5th graders attend the annual safety patrol trip to Washington, D.C. for the first time in 5 years.  Most schools get to go every year, but not this one.  Let's help them get there this year!

What We Need & What You Get

  • These students need to raise a total of $20,000.  This is an overwhelming amount of money and task for the children of this school. Our goal includes the transportation, hotel, meals, admissions, shirts, visors, & tote bags. 
  • You will get personalized "Thank You" cards from the students and the satisfaction of sending a child to D.C for a once-in-a-lifetime experience.
  • If the children do not raise the funds, the money they have already raised will be lost on deposits and either they will not be able to go or only a few children out of the total safety patrol will get to go.  They've all worked so hard to raise the funds they need for all of them to go together and just need a little more help.  They are a team and no child should be left out.  Please help every child attend this important trip.

The Impact

This trip will impact these children in significant ways.  It will help them see first hand the opportunities our country can provide them if they stay in school, work hard and get a good education.  Help keep their ambitious flame lit.

  • This project is important as it will inspire these children to work hard, stay in school and become productive members of society.  
  • This project will also inspire the younger students to work hard so they too may be able to attend this trip in future years.  It will show them that the community really does care and anything is possible with hard work and determination.
  • As Martin Luther King, Jr. said, "I have a dream".  This trip is these children's dream.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot make a monetary contribution, then please share this site with others via Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, Google+ or e-mails to your family, friends and circles of influence.  Additionally, all the students at this school are in constant need of food, clothing and school supplies.  You can contribute any of these items by contacting the school directly to make arrangements for drop-off or to help with beautification projects constantly in progress.

  • Please help get the word out by "liking" this campaign and sharing it on your social media sites such as Facebook, Twitter, Linked In and others
  • Use the "share" function on this site to share this campaign.

PLEASE DONATE AND HELP THESE KIDS GET TO WASHINGTON D.C.!   

THANK YOU FOR HELPING!

story:
Update

It takes $500 to send one DDF Competitor to the State Competition.  We are trying to send FIFTEEN.  Thank you so much to those who have contributed so far, but we still have a long way to go to get all fifteen students to Anchorage!  The State Competition will be held on Thursday, February 13th through Saturday, February 15th.  Help get us to Anchorage!

A Little About Us

Sitka High School's Drama, Debate, and Forensics (D.D.F.) team has a legacy of success.  Beyond our many state competition trophies and stories of student accomplishment, we are a quirky, artistic, often outspoken, little family at Sitka High School.  

Our season runs from August until February, and includes five different regional meets before we travel to the state competition.  Because we are situated in Sitka, on Baranof Island, in Southeast Alaska, traveling to a competition means more than hopping on a bus; in fact, it typically means traveling for four to five days, hopping on ferries or planes, housing with local families in our destination-town, and sometimes (to the detriment of the coaches' sanity) a night or two sleeping on a gymnasium floor as a team.

By donating to the Sitka High School DDF team, you are helping the team travel to this year's final state competition in Anchorage! Unfortunately a reality of participating in a sport or activity in Southeast Alaska often carries a big price tag for students; this year has been especially difficult.  Help our students make it to the state competition!

What We Need and the Impact

As you can see here, the goal is set at $500.  This is because we want to set a reasonable goal, as there is a penalty if you don't reach your goal amount.  Consider this, though: $500 is enough to send ONE STUDENT to the state competition.  We need to send FIFTEEN. 

Please, think about what an awesome opportunity it is to send a student to the state competition and donate a few dollars.  And once you've done that, tell your friends and family to spare a little money to help a kid out, too.  Every bit of money we make will help send more kids to the state competition.  

Anything you can contribute is deeply appreciated and in the true spirit of Sitka's Drama, Debate, and Forensics team, it will take a great deal of us working together to keep the Sitka High School Drama, Debate, and Forensics team great!

Other Ways You Can Help

For those of you who live outside of Sitka, this is the best way that you can help our team travel.  If you do live in Sitka, we also encourage you to attend our State Piece Showcase and Silent Auction on January 31st at 7pm in the Sitka High School Performing Arts Center.  There may be some other events and fundraising coming up soon, so check here for updates!  

Thank you all for your support.

story:
About Me

My name is  Robin Lowey, and I’m the Founder, Publisher, Curator and Editor-in-Chief of the popular online magazine Epochalips: Smart Lesbian Commentary.  Since 2010, I’ve published close to 1,000 articles, interviews and Op-ed pieces, each from a variety of well-known LGBTQ contributors and guest writers. In addition to my work publishing the Epochalips: Smart Lesbian Commentary online magazine, I’m also an established Graphic Designer/Creative Director with over 20 years experience in writing, publication design and printing. As a member of the LGBT Speakers Bureau (an organization that goes into local high schools to help debunk stereotypes about LGBTQ people) I know this book is urgently needed at this time in history.  On a personal note, I’m also a proud, pioneering lesbian mom of two now adult sons born in 1990 and 1996, respectively. 

Why This Book? Why Now?

With the upcoming Trump Administration taking place in January 2017, it’s extremely important and needed for us to provide as much positive education about LGBTQ history, community, and our contributions to society, as possible. Like you, I feel strongly that history must never be altered, lost, or drowned out by those in power.

But regardless of the uncertainty of the upcoming Administration, today’s LGBTQ youth need to know who their female heroes are, and on whose backs their newfound freedom is based upon.

I think its safe to assume that soon, in an effort to satisfy the new curriculum requirement, there will be a poster of Harvey Milk in most California classrooms. With all due respect to history, while Milk helped make real changes to the civil rights laws, there are also specific women who provided cultural contributions that allowed our community to THRIVE.  I will feature many key women who (not unlike recent Presidential Medal of Freedom award winner Ellen DeGeneres) came out early in their lives and forged a path specifically for the future of lesbian culture. We need to celebrate our history, and more importantly, let it be more widely known for the sake of our community, our kids and our grandkids.

How You Can Help (It’s EASY!) 

Let’s Make our Lesbian Legacy Stronger than Ever! I want to seize the moment and build a legacy to continue and provide a rich library of resources for the next generation. My goal is to get this book into the hands of many young adults in the Bay Area as the FAIR Act is implemented in the public school curriculum by 2017. My long-range goal is to find a publisher to get this book in the hands of EVERY public school student in California, and continue to create several more volumes featuring many other important women. You can be a part of creating this historical legacy!

It’s so easy!  If you contribute, the money will be used for printing and publishing expenses for an initial run of up to 1000 books. Books will be gifted to YOU, our donors, as well as over 150 public schools in the Bay Area. Remaining books will be sold online and in bookstores. 50% of any profits from those sales will be distributed evenly between four deserving LGBTQ organizations: Our Families Coalition, which supports equity for families and children, SAGE Services and Advocacy for Elders, NCLR National Center for Lesbian Rights and the Horizons Foundation, a community foundation dedicated to the LGBT community.

What Exactly is Game Changers?

Created as a richly-designed interactive package, this large format book will dedicate six pages to each woman featured. There will also be a pull-out Game Card which highlights ‘fun facts’ about each woman. This deck of cards is a fun way to get people to play and interact with the women in the book.

Even if you can’t donate, please share with those in your network who can!  Use the Indiegogo sharing tools, send personal emails, and please share on all your social media channels. I'll be providing blurbs and special insider incentives to push out periodically. 

LET'S DO THIS TOGETHER! NOW, MORE THAN EVER, IT IS IMMENSELY IMPORTANT TO COMBAT THE NEWLY ELECTED ANTI-LGBTQ AGENDA AND YOUR HELP IS GREATLY APPRECIATED!

THANK YOU!

story:
Hello!

Thanks for considering our project for your help. My name is Ronn Colanino and I have been a teacher my entire life. I am currently teaching in a school that was built in the 70s and has not been updated. I have 31 kids in my overcrowded class including a large ESOL population. I am trying to instill pride in my  students and a will to succeed and do their best.  It is hard to do with a room that is crowded with broken, unmatched desks, littered with wires that are hard to hide, woodwork that is scratched, old and messy, cabinets with broken handles and not much room to move in general. Not all my students have desks. Three sit at tables with no place for their belongings. 

I am dreaming big here. I would like to raise enough money to buy new desks, a DVD instead of the VCR we have, new wall coverings (like cork so I can easily display kids' work), perhaps a nice area rug, some decent shelving and if I have enough left over, to buy some books and repair existing cabinets. 

Every penny will be spent on my students and I thank you in advance for your help.

Sincerely,

Ronn

story:
Hi Everyone,


My name is Clara Lamai Nødskov Holm, I ́m 20 years old and my dream is to attend Marist College in New York and play Division 1 Soccer.

I’m Danish and part Thai, grew up in Denmark and attended International school near Copenhagen. My family spent a few years in the UK and I have always appreciated having a cultured network from all parts of the world. I graduated high school with an IB Diploma (International Baccalaureate) to have a better chance of taking my B.A. degree abroad.

After graduation I spent two years working, traveling and doing internships, before applying to college.

In 2013, I spent three months as an intern at Jimmy Choo Ltd in London, in their Communications Department, working with digital media. It was an amazing experience and I have been interested in studying media and productions ever since.

July 2013, I backpacked around America with my best friend for three months, traveling from the East Coast to the West Coast. In New York, I met some fantastic people who introduced me to Marist College.

Marist is a small private liberal arts college on the Hudson River in upstate New York. It has outstanding facilities for “Media Studies and Production in Film”, an incredible campus, a great selection of internships in New York City and also a Division 1 Women’s soccer team, The Marist Redfoxes.

In Denmark education is free and thus, I don’t have a college fund, but when Marist College caught my attention, I was certain it was the school for me. I would love to study and live on a college campus and to be able to play soccer at such a competitive level, with the students I go to school with.

I was well aware of the fact that as a European the process of getting into an American College and funding the tuition could be challenging, but I was up for it.

March 2014, I got my acceptance letter from Marist and my dream came much closer to reality. As I am not able to cover the expenses on my own. I began applying for funds in Denmark in order to achieve my goal. The chance of getting financial support in Denmark for a BA in the US are slender, so I figured that my American College dream might lie in getting on the Marist soccer team, and potentially getting financial aid to finish my education.

I began training soccer intensively and working out every day. I know that getting a chance to tryout and possibly make the team is hard work and requires certain skills, so I stepped my game up both on the field and at the gym.  

I believe I have what it takes to play at such a competitive level. Soccer has been a part of my life for 12 years. I have contacted Marist’s soccer coach and I am eagerly awaiting her response. I am hoping to get a tryout when I attend Marist this coming Fall.

As I need your help for my first year at Marist, I am setting up this crowd-fund. Tuition is 45,000$ a year and I am 20,000$ short. By helping me attend Marist, you give me a chance to make the soccer team and fulfilling my college dream. 

As I plan to study Media Studies & Production, I have decided to produce a video about the process of getting into college in America, how it is to live on campus and my journey to becoming a Redfox.  Such a video might serve to inspire other international students who have the same ambitions that I do.

As I need to start paying my tuition shortly, I would really appreciate your help. Give me a chance to show you, that I have what it takes to make the team. Please, share my story and support my dream of attending Marist College and becoming  a Redfox! 

          You can also transfer money directly using the Danish Iphone App:                                                                    MOBILEPAY by Danske Bank

                                                    Transfer to: 53232300


                                                                Thank You,
                                                                                                                Clara Lamai
