impact not just now while they're in school, but in the future in their 
community.So, what do you say? If everyone reading this donated just $10, our campaign would be over in a day. For just $5 or $10 (or more, if you're able), you can dramatically impact the quality of the lives of over 1,100 students at Patterson High, as well as their families, neighbors, and community. Think about that.Other Ways You Can HelpNot able to donate right now?Not a problem!Here's some things you can do to help us in other ways:
Help us get the word out - make some noise!
If you've got radio, TV, or media connections, we'd love to share this project and our work with them!

If you're online, you've probably got a Facebook page, maybe you're even on Twitter and Pinterest. Use the IndieGoGo share tools to share this campaign with the people in your life.

story:
Short Summary

Hello! We are the 2015 8th grade from Stowe Middle School who have been learning Chinese for two years. Every year the 8th grade goes to Boston Chinatown. Going to Chinatown will give us a chance to use our language skills in a natural environment, talking to real people with both English and Chinese, and immersing ourselves in Chinese culture. This is an amazing learning opportunity to take us out of the school environment and into the real world and practice what we've learned.

Once we reach Boston, a four-hour drive from our town, we will eat a dim sum lunch, then go to a Kung Fu class. The next day, we will visit the Museum of Fine Arts and take a Chinese cooking class from a chef from Tianjin, in northern China. 

Unfortunately, the school budget does not include funding for this trip. We need you to help by donating and spreading the word!

What We Need & What You Get

In order to make our goal for this trip, we need to raise $1300.  Raising this money helps to make this trip more affordable for the students learning Chinese in our grade.  The largest costs that need covering are transportation and lodging, due to the distance between Boston and our homes in Stowe, Vermont.  

To thank you, we have a variety of amazing perks ranging from a high five, a song about you, to some souvenirs from Boston Chinatown.  We really appreciate anything you are able to donate, no matter how small. We are excited for this opportunity; it is the kind of thing that might occur only once in a lifetime.

The Impact

We have all been learning Chinese for a year now. And while we have a blast in the classroom writing characters, there are some things that we can only learn through hands-on experience. Going to Boston Chinatown will further enrich our knowledge of the Chinese language, and immerse us in authentic Chinese culture, as well as expanding our knowledge of cultural diversity. It will give us a chance to expand on what we have learned in class, and experience the things we have not. We will get to connect with people, see the sights, eat the food, and enjoy our overall progression in the world of Chinese. We are all dedicated to learning Chinese, and we think that going on this trip will really help improve our progress and success. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't afford to donate any money, you could always share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Google Plus and any other social media you can think of. Every little bit counts, and getting the word out is helping. Thank you!

story:
Help HIV Activist Paul Lhungdim defeat the Hep-C Virus and #CurePaul

Paul Lhungdim (43 years)has been working with the Delhi Network for Positive People (DNP+)* as the project coordinator for over two years.  In his role as project coordinator, he is dedicated to securing access to treatment for DNP+ members on daily basis. As an HIV activist, he has played critical role in the organization by rigorously monitoring stocks of HIV drugs in Delhi; he also played a crucial role in reporting logistical bottlenecks to the publicly-administered AIDS program, thus ensuring uninterrupted supplies of drugs and diagnostics for HIV treatment in Delhi. 

However, his health has started to fail. Paul has been diagnosed with stage 3 hepatitis C. To translate in laymen’s term, Paul is at the last stage before the onset of liver cirrhosis. In addition to impacting his quality of life, his condition is affecting his working capacity.

Treatment with new hepatitis C medicines (direct acting antivirals – DAAs) will preserve liver function and health, while lack of treatment risks vital damage. A fixed combination of 2 DAAs (Sofosbuvir + Ledipasvir) offers a cure, but at a substantial cost. For Paul, six months of treatment with the combination obtained through a special name patient import process will cost 3390 USD that is equivalent to his one year’s salary. With three children, a wife and an ailing father to support, the exorbitant cost means this drug is simply priced out of his reach. 

Paul says: 

"I have never felt worried in the last 20 years since I have been HIV positive as the drugs have been readily available from the government. But with no support from the government and medicines being so expensive for Hep-C treatment, I am always stressed about what will happen to me and my family now. 

I suffer from constant weakness and feel frustrated all the time due to my inability to work for the community. "

Sofosbuvir + Ledipasvir has a near 100% cure rate for genotype 1, a figure almost as impressive as Paul’s current adherence to his HIV drug regimen. Through discipline, he has brought his HIV to undetectable status. Paul has shown the same perseverance in his efforts to diagnosis and document the progression of his hepatitis infection. DNP+ was there for Paul, and he has in turn dedicated himself to “paying it forward”. We ask for your help in ensuring that he will be healthy enough to continue making these contributions. In helping Paul obtain treatment, you will be contributing to those whom he is able to positively influence.

Please take this opportunity to have a positive influence on Paul’s life. What we need is 100 donations of about $35 each for Paul to start his treatment.Thank you.

* The Delhi Network for Positive People is an organization dedicatedly working on providing absolutely vital services for people living with HIV/AIDS in India’s capital area. The organization has built a community of positive individuals of all ages and from all walks of life. That community continues to grow, not simply because DNP+ has saved countless lives through advocacy and outreach, but because of its demonstrated ability to improve lives by providing treatment support to its members and broader hope for those facing stigma and discrimination. When DNP+ is not holding the government accountable for fulfilling its responsibility to provide treatment, it is working with the government to provide crucial logistical help.

story:
A friend told me that they are tired of hearing the constant sad stories of poverty stricken women in the world. And that people don’t respond to stories of the sad truth of others’ lives anymore. They said we would all rather just hear of only the happy parts of our existence. Would you agree? Have we grown so insensitive, please tell me you have not lost the capacity for respect, humanity, and honest work. This is our story.

After seeing how the Cambodian women live, Olivera Djokovic made the decision to remain in Cambodia after traveling here to visit her son. She was introduced to Love Nicholson who also came to Cambodia to learn of what the people here must endure. They quickly joined forces because it seemed the right thing to do.

Art solution has some big plans for the future; among other things, an employment plan as part of training in the design studio, which we intend to open. We recognize the need for corporate social responsibility by investing in human resources that have been largely ignored. “If we give only material assistance, we are only supporting a system that produces victims”.

 

"Vision of proposed studio"

Art Solution is a company that has 15 years of experience in decorative gift wrapping, decorating weddings, and other festivities; quality balloons and invitations for all events. This we want to do and in Cambodia, to train and employ women who are marginalized because we believe that work is a requirement for independence and the continuation of life worthy of all. Employment for women has therapeutic significance of the return of confidence, self-esteem and re-establish control over their lives. This will help not only women and girls but also their families.

 

For women who want to be educated and to work independently to open a design studio. Our plan is that in this studio women learn .........

What is our mission !?!

1.            To help improve the literacy skills of everyone that wants to learn, in their native language, as well as training in English.

2.            To offer cultural immersion with westerners as an equal to foster a healthy exchange of ideas, skills, and viewpoints

3.            To improve the business and marketing scope of all students so they may use what they learn here to permanently improve their lives.

4.            To offer a rich course of artistic development to aid in psychological and therapeutic stability, as well as an introduction to marketable skills.

5.            To offer all services to our students free of charge.*

Our example can and should serve as a prelude to the practice of good and responsible business, which would mean that all of you who are reading this share positive examples and urge employers to allow marginalized women a chance for a new beginning, because they certainly deserve it, and their ability to work not should be ignored for the sake of the past in which they were exploited.

I want to point out that we not an NGO, nor are we a charity. We just want to do what we do best, and to help as much as we can.

We want everyone who sees our campaign to instantly realize the good we can do in this world, and to do their best to help us financially with what they can, and of course to share this campaign video with as many people as you can. Thank you.

 

It is our belief, that art and the expression of creativity can be a very healthy, & therapeutic exercise. The peoples of Cambodia, and their women most specifically have been traumatized by years of genocide, war, lack of education or infrastructure, and systemic social abuses. It could be years or perhaps generations before, as a people, the Cambodians can find their strength to grow in a healthy manner again. So, we at Art Solution are asking for your help in building a design studio to act as a safe haven for those that wish to develop their love of art and the creative spirit. It is our intention to work closely with the Royal fine arts university, & the Phnom Penh International Institute of the Arts to offer training and developmental, artistic instruction coupled with the language and business skills needed to make real change in their owns lives. There is a large art community here of expats that have pledged their time, skill, and love of art and humanity to help others to grow, heal, and create again. 

 

Our Goals

•             to bring artistic and creative development the attention it deserves as a therapeutic exercise

•             to offer some of the most marginalized women and girls of the society a path back to being healthy contributors to the society

•             to help influence the importance of spending on the arts in schools by local and national governments

•             to foster a meaningful and permanent coalition of local and international NGO’s and charities for maximum effectiveness

•             to help bring balance to extreme economic disparity in the lives of those that have felt they had few or no options

•             to develop effective satellite programs in the provinces and rural areas

•             and to eventually help develop commerce in areas of the country with little or no industry

 

How we say THANK YOU

And in the spirit of fostering creativity and joy, we want to share our gift as a small thank you for those that help support our dream. We have prepared a series of thank you gifts so that you too may explore your own creative urges.

Acknowledgement as a donor on the A/S website < $15

Art Solution Asia logo pencil / charcoal set $20

Art Solution Asia pencil box $30 (personalized)

Art Solution Asia tee shirts $40

Art Solution Asia tote bag $50

Art Solution Asia seasonal card set $75

Art Solution Asia seasonal card subscription $100

Art Solution Asia sponsorship of a local student artist $175

All the above $500 & an Art Solution Asia DYI gift wrapping kit,

Thank you for your support, we thank you for helping to spread the word of our work here.

Notes on the Design studio portion*

I want to paint a picture for you of a young lady that serves as a waitress at a small Chinese restaurant here in Phnom Penh. She works about 11 hours a day and probably has one day off per week. She’s young, only about 21 years old but pretty and she has an easy smile. She speaks no English really but she always nods politely when I thank her for her service. I imagine her perhaps dreaming of painting, or needle work, or even recreating beautiful scenes using decoupage if only she had the training, materials, or encouragement that it wasn’t just a waste of time.

I picture her coming into the studio for an hour or 2 on her day off and mingling for the first time with westerners, and not in a service position. I picture her gradually improving her English as the other Cambodian art students from the institute or the Fine art school help her to understand all that she has access to. I picture her eyes growing wide with excitement as she sees her creations garner the applause and appreciation of the teachers and her fellow artists. I see her, slowly over the weeks, learning about other cultures and ways of approaching art and life. I see her language improving as she gains more confidence in herself as a woman as well as an artist. I see her making friends and connections that were not possible before. I see her learning the basics of marketing her art and her developing talent. I see her world changing by her own hand, and I see hope.

Stretch Goals

When our program reaches the goal we have set, we will be able to launch a rich program or academic and artistic growth for hundreds of women and girls here in Phnom Penh.

But if we can reach double that amount, we will be able to begin plans for a second Design Studio for Women & Girls in Siem Reap, a cultural mecca here in Cambodia as the gateway to historical Angkor Wat.

We truly want to help as many people as we can to feel the joy creativity and art in their lives, and with your help we can help more girls than we ever thought possible and one day soon, expand our programs into the provinces and rural areas.

Thank you.

Olivera Djokovic & Love Nicholson

Art Solution Asia.

artsolution.asia@gmail.com

story:
Summary

The Non-Profit Sooke Sailing Association is starting a Sailing School in Sooke and need some help to get it off the ground. What we need right now is an inflatable Safety Boat and two trailers to store and move the fleet around. We also want to make the school accessible to families in low income situations. 

Details

Currently the Mobile Optimist Sailing School (MOSS) put on by BC Sailing is providing the Instructors, Optimist Sailboats, three kayaks and a safety boat for the School. Their mandate is to come to a new community and within three years have it operating on its own. We need to purchase a Safety boat, 12 optimist sailing Dinghies, two trailers to store and carry it all on and to train at least three trained instructors to run it on our ourselves.

It will cost just over $5000 for an inflatable dinghy with an aluminum bottom (for shallow water rescues) and a motor.

Two trailers to haul the 12 Optimist Sailing Dinghies the Safety Boat and three kayaks will cost approximately $3000

We will purchase as much infrastructure as we can and any left over money will go towards getting the kids having trouble getting the $250 a class cost together a spot in the class.

We will run classes with MOSS to make money to purchase the school boats. This summer we will run three classes and when they fill up (22 kids each) we will make almost enough money to buy 3 more sailing dinghies for our school.

We had a one week sailing school last summer and it filled up with a few weeks’ notice. Running the school gave us $1040 towards buying our first slightly used Optimist Sailing Dinghy $1500. Association Members chipped in the rest and we now have our first boat towards our goal of having a full time sailing school in Sooke. One of our members made an hand made an Optimist last year and we will use that boat for the school as well. Now that we have our first year done we will get $1300 for each full class towards the purchase of used boats. 

 

Check out what Kelowna Yacht Club has done, that is what we are doing http://www.kelownayachtclub.com/Sailing-School-...  

 

About Sooke Sailing Association

 Constitution                               

a) to promote and facilitate sailing education across all age ranges

b) to promote water safety and seamanship in the Sooke area

c) to promote the physical, sport and social aspects of sailing and share a common interest and knowledge Base.

 

Our first project is working with BC Sailing  and the MOSS Program to continue a kids sailing program in Sooke this summer

maybe even day classes in the schools.

Teaching children from the ages of 6 to 14 to safely sail and have fun at Sooke.

As the children get older they are confident to move on to racing, teaching sailing or advanced sailing classes.

If you would like more information on the Mobile Optimist Sailing School (MOSS) or want to sign up go to bcsailing.com 

We are supported by donations from the following local business' and groups:

$200 from Dr. Joslin, Dr. Morin and Associates Optometrists  in Sooke 

$200 from The Sooke Rotary Club Both were for one year membership in the BC Sailing Association

Mariners Village Sooke BC has donated us the use of the Marina, and a room for classes and storage
story_txt:
Summary
The Non-Profit Sooke Sailing Association is starting a Sailing School in Sooke and need some help to get it off the ground. What we need right now is an inflatable Safety Boat and two trailers to store and move the fleet around. We also want to make the school accessible to families in low income situations. 
Details
Currently the Mobile Optimist Sailing School (MOSS) put on by BC Sailing is providing the Instructors, Optimist Sailboats, three kayaks and a safety boat for the School. Their mandate is to come to a new community and within three years have it operating on its own. We need to purchase a Safety boat, 12 optimist sailing Dinghies, two trailers to store and carry it all on and to train at least three trained instructors to run it on our ourselves.
It will cost just over $5000 for an inflatable dinghy with an aluminum bottom (for shallow water rescues) and a motor.
Two trailers to haul the 12 Optimist Sailing Dinghies the Safety Boat and three kayaks will cost approximately $3000
We will purchase as much infrastructure as we can and any left over money will go towards getting the kids having trouble getting the $250 a class cost together a spot in the class.
We will run classes with MOSS to make money to purchase the school boats. This summer we will run three classes and when they fill up (22 kids each) we will make almost enough money to buy 3 more sailing dinghies for our school.
We had a one week sailing school last summer and it filled up with a few weeks’ notice. Running the school gave us $1040 towards buying our first slightly used Optimist Sailing Dinghy $1500. Association Members chipped in the rest and we now have our first boat towards our goal of having a full time sailing school in Sooke. One of our members made an hand made an Optimist last year and we will use that boat for the school as well. Now that we have our first year done we will get $1300 for each full class towards the purchase of used boats. 
 
Check out what Kelowna Yacht Club has done, that is what we are doing http://www.kelownayachtclub.com/Sailing-School-...

story:
Short Summary

Get Ready to Learn (GRTL) is a 15-20 minute sensory-motor yoga curriculum for students regardless of age or ability as developed by Anne Buckley-Reen, OTR, RYT in 2008.  Anne and a group of highly trained clinicians are volunteering their time and expertise to the students at the Amrit Center for Special Needs in Coimbatore India, http://www.amrit-ifsn.com/home.html, and we need your support to make this possible. Pediatric expert occupational therapist and registered yoga teacher, Anne Buckley Reen has been working with children for over thirty years.  Through her intensive training wih Sonia Sumar (developer of Yoga for the Special Child,http://www.specialyoga.org/) she developed this curriculum based yoga therapy program that focuses on creating an environment that is conducive for learning. This is done through use of therapeutic protocols to facilitate optimal level of attention, performance, behavior, and communication; and providing staff with strategies to optimize developmental, academic, and social outcomes.

GRTL is currently implemented in over 500 classrooms in New York City District 75 schools throughout the five boroughs as well as classrooms in Arizona, California, Connenctlicut, Illinois, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, New Hampshire, New Jersey, Vermont, and London, England.

GTRL is researched as being an effective, evidence based, method of improving students performance.
The successful outcomes of using GRTL with students with Autistic spectrum disorders have been published in the American Journal of Occupational Therapy September 2012.

The Impact

First:
Training the staff and families in how to use the GRTL curriculum at the Amrit Center
Second:
Hands on assistance by the expert volunteers with the staff and parents at the Amrit Center to ensure the highest level of training and continued work with GRTL program after our volunteers leave.
Third:
Hands on intervention for students with more specialized needs for individualized yoga programs designed by the volunteer clinicians and to be implemented by the Amrit Center staff and parents.
Last:
Ongoing communication with the staff at the Amrit Center to ensure that the GRTL program is carried out daily for maximum benefit for students, parents, and staff.
 

What We Need:

The vounteers need round trip air fare and to Combatoire, India, and transportation to and from the Center.  There are 4 volunteers. Airfare  and transporattion is approximately $2,000.00/pp for a total of $8,000.00

Food and accomodations for the vounteers for the duration of the trip approximately $1000.00

Taxes, fees, and documentary costs: $1,000.00

Total funds needed for basic costs: $10,000.00

Any extra funds rasied will be donated to the Amrit Center for Children with Special Needs.

What You Get:

$25.00 donation- e-card and pictures of the trip and our work with the students.

$50.00-Privat link to the documentary of the trip and the impact this work had for these students, parents, and staff. You will also get a special thanks and acknowledgment on our trip Blog.

$100.00-Invitation to attend a private yoga class and have tea with the vounteers following class.  This will be available to the first 25 individuals who donate $100.00.  The class will take place at a specific NYC location on a specific date determined on the availability of the volunteers.


$250.00-Invitation to attend a Restorative Yoga class with specfic techniques and positions targeted to your individualized needs.  This invitation will be avaiable to the first 35 individuals who donate $250.00.  The class will take place at a specific NYC location on a specific date determined on the availability of the volunteers.

 $500.00-Invitation to attend a community style ear acupuncture session focused on stress reducation.  Individuals will recieve a stress reduction ear acupuncture point protocol and relax for 30 minutes.  The session will take place at a specific NYC location on a specific date determined on the availability of our NYS licensed acupuncturist volunteering her time for the event.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not contribute we could still use your help in spreading the word to make this trip possible.

story:
Dominique Lucas Is A Fifteen Year Old High School Student Set On Going To China.

Dominique is a very responsible teenager, she helps her mom at home with her baby brother, she's a volunteer assistant at Sunday School, and works at a local daycare. Her potential is apparent to everyone that knows her, it is so evident, that her high school guidance counselor nominated her to become a candidate for the People to People Student Ambassador Program. A little while later Dominique received an invitation from People to People, and after submitting an application, acquiring letters of recommendation, and successfully completing an interview she was accepted into the program.

People to People Ambassador Programs provide opportunities for international educational travel on all seven continents for students grades 5-12 and college. Their mission is “to bridge cultural and political borders through education and exchange, creating global citizens and making the world a better place for future generations.”

Dominique has the opportunity to go to China for 17 days, from July 3 – 19, 2013. She will visit a total of six cities including Beijing, Shanghai, and Xi'an. She realizes this is an amazing opportunity for someone her age. What she likes about China the most is the language, and looks forward to learning Chinese. What interests her the most about learning Chinese is that it is a character based language difficult for English speakers to learn.

 

What She Needs

The tuition for this educational experience begins at a little over $7,000. Family and friends have all pledged to give what they can to help her manifest this opportunity. She would like your help as well.

In total Dominique will need $10,000 dollars. Whether she reaches this goal or not, the money she raises through this campaign will go towards:

  • Tuition

  • Passport

  • Travel Gear

  • Petty Cash

as well as some perks...

Her trip will not be all fun and games as the program is designed so that students will gain an authentic understanding of the local people and culture in the country they visit. Journaling her experience, visiting local schools, and completing a home-stay, are some of the educational activities she will be required to do.

 

How You Can Help

There are three ways you can help Dominique: give based on the available perks or contribute any amount without selecting a perk, you can use your credit card or debit card, and whether you give $1 or $100 she'll be that much closer to reaching her goal; get the word out, tell your family, friends, and co-workers about this impressive young woman working toward funding her trip to China; and through the power of social media, share this campaign on your Blog, Twitter, Tumblr, and Facebook.

THANK YOU!!!

You can find out more about People to People by visiting their site HERE.

story:
Short Summary

We are a group of students at the Rhode Island School of Design, from a wide range of backgrounds, who all have found yoga, meditation, and other internal arts as an important catalyst in our creative practice. We wanted to share and celebrate this experience with the community. We are expecting at least 200 attendees at this one-day event. 

The event will feature 14 teachers teaching a variety of classes. These include a different styles of yoga as well as qi-gong and soft martial arts. There will also be speaking events, a musical perfromance, and a space offering various types of natural healing modalities such as Thai massage. 

How You Can Help

This event is a labor of love. Even though we are a non-profit, there are still various costs required to run a festival. These Include:

  • $1000 to pay the teachers
  • $600 rent parking for our food vendors
  • $420 rent the stage
  • $250 Printing promotional materials, and advertising fees
  • $400 Pay for website creation
  • $50 Signage
  • $25 coupons and items for goody bags to be given to
  • $50 Incidentals
  • $200 Projected additional costs, including catering, parking, compensating food vend
  • $270 Fees for Indiegogo

We have the enthusiasm and drive, but this funding will be crucial to ensure that this festival can grow to it's full potential, if our goal isn't met we could be forced to scale down the number of teachers and attendees.

In addition to knowing you had a hand in making this festival possible, we have many perks to offer. Our students from India have sourced a variety of  unique bags and apparel that have beem hand embroidered by Indian tribal artisans. (Check out the gallery for images!)

We are also offering original artworks from artists and designers attending the Rhode Island School of Design. These incude artworks in diverse media, as well as hand silk-screened posters inspired by the festival. You can view the artworks here http://www.flickr.com/photos/bodhispring/sets/7....

Even if you can't contribute monetarily we would greatly appreciate if you shared this campaign with your friends, and family.

story:
What is this campaign for?

This past year I have been blessed with the opportunity to be a part of a medical sciences class at the Bollman Technical Education Center, where they teach you about specific careers and all of the materials that go along with the career of choice. Each class at BTEC is a part of a larger organization (much like DECA) and medical sciences is a part of HOSA, Health Occupations Students of America. HOSA has two competitions each year, one on the state level and one on the national level. Nationals is costly and I would more than love to be able to go this summer.

How do you get to Nationals?

Nationals is a two step process that is simple yet very challenging. Like any national competition you have to medal gold silver or bronze at the state level, but in oder to make it to state you must take a written test and make the top 10 percent of all the test takers. 

What did I make Nationals for?

My Biomedical Debate team and I placed 2nd in the state and have ultamitely decided that we want to represent the state of Colorado in the upcoming national competiions. :) Biomedical Debate is exactly as it sounds, we have a medically related debate topic that we had to research in preparation for the tournement. The topic this year is the effects of social media on health, and though it was challenging, we managed to take second, being just shy of first. 

Where is Nationals?

Walt Disney's Disney World in Orlando Florida. Cool right? I have never actually been to Disney World so I was shocked to see the prices of basically everything there. I would love to go for the first time in 17 years, but man is it expensive. 

How I came across this sight

I actually have no idea what I'm doing :) this sight is completely new to me and I have absolutely no idea how this works. A friend of mine in a class had overheard me mention how expensive nationals is and suggested for me to join this sight... so here I am. 

Additional information about me

Just in case you were wondering why I'm taking a medical sciences class, my dream since the 7th grade was to become a verterinarian, and I wanted to learn more and more about health care. Not only did my teacher (former CNA) teach me about the field in general but she helped open my eyes to the world of health care and all of the careers in it. Now not only do I still have interest in becoming a verterinatian, but now I also have interest in becoming a general care physician. Decisions decisions.

story:
Help Serena's Education!

Serena is A 16 year old Homeschooler who lives in the small town backlands of Yucca Valley, California. 

What I will be doing.

This 5-week long Epic Movement trip to Brazil put on by Wonderlarks Abbi Miller and Megan Lipsett (who are both certified yoga instructors) is focused on learning about Body, Mind and Health.   We will be participating in activities that fulfill aspects of our brains, bodies, and higher selves; as well as consciously contributing to the cultures we are interacting with. 


Throughout the trip, we will practice yoga, Capoeira, aerial silks and trapeze.  These movement modalities offer the potential for play, focus, balance, strength, community, and self-awareness.  Participants will return with a strong foundation in aerial arts, which is a hot new marketable skill.

This Educational Experience and the skills I would develope mean so much to me. One of the most important things to me is that I would be making and learning how to keep myself healthy and happy. Becoming worldly knowledgable and learning about a new culture and language.

 I need your help to raise the amount of $6000.

Where the money is going.

4,999 for Wonderlarks tuition. Includes all meals, transportation, housing and activities throughout Brazil.

1,000 for the flight to and from Brazil.

I have to do it in 1 month and I'm going to be doing all that I can to raise the money. 

 

My Perks.

I'm offering some awesome unique perks for donating. (you can donate any amount of money, not just the amounts listed)

I am really interested in photography so my perks are based on the beautiful photos that I will capture in Brazil. I will prefessionally print them for you so they are ready to be displayed on your wall.

So please take just a minute of your time to help me reach for my dream. 

Every little bit helps.

If I don't reach my goal all of the money will be saved for one of Wonderlarks up coming adventures.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, I'd love for you to share this campaign on Facebook or your blog or with you extended family! 

Thank you for supporting me!

story:
Critical Years is an education platform that helps parents and early childhood professionals with the brain development of children.


Background

The first 5 years of brain development are the most critical in every persons life. Research shows that if you get the early years right, people go on to be positive contributors in society. Get it wrong and people will have learning problems in the future.

The first 5 years are more important than K-12 and University combined, yet early education is one of the most neglected, over regulated and misunderstood fields in most countries throughout the world. Worse still, if you're a new parent, you're expected to know everything about child development when your first child is born.

Did you know that something simple and innocent like encouraging a child to walk too soon can have a long term consequence on their development? Is there a problem with a child who talks late? That child may go on to be a great speaker. Every child learns differently. What matters is receiving a rich set of experiences that help encourage brain development.

Yes, you could read a thousand books on child development. However, do these books address the unique requirements of your child at the right time? And who has the time to read, interpret and decide what is appropriate?

As parents, we all need to accept that most of us have no idea what we're doing.... until now.


What is Critical Years?

Critical Years is an expert system and monitoring tool. It helps develop and capture the uniqueness of every child.

As you might imagine, you can't put a 6 month old baby in front of a computer and expect them to do a multiple choice exam. Instead, you can create a real world environment with objects and experiences that encourage certain types of behaviour. Once you see a behaviour, you record it.

Critical Years learns from your observations. Then it suggests new experiences to encourage further development. Each set of experiences are unique and adjusted to the requirements of each child. We have included over 4,000+ experiences and 3,000+ resources based on academic research from across the world.

In addition to learning and development, Critical Years provides you with the ability to journal your child's learning experiences with written and photographic evidence, and communicate with other family members, early education professionals or other professionals such as speech therapists, etc. about your child.


Privacy and Security

What about the sensitive nature of child information? We can't put video, photographic or written content on services like YouTube, Facebook, Google+, Amazon Web Services, etc. for obvious privacy and security reasons. We had to develop our own in-house secure storage services for content. All information is tranferred over SSL/https - similar to banks.


Who can use Critical Years?

Critical Years can be used by parents, long day care services, family/home care services, pre-schools, kindergartens, out of school care, etc. It can also be used by related interested people such as family members and specialists in other fields (doctors, psychologists, speech therapists, etc.)


Our Goal

Help us bring Critical Years to the USA and the rest of the world.

Until now, the project has been entirely self funded. We have spent countless hours making it a reality. We have trialled it in Australia and we now feel it's time to make it available to the rest of the world.

The goal of this project is to:

1. Make the service multilingual and support different languages and dialects across the world.
2. Translate 8,000+ text resources to Spanish (40% of Americans speak Spanish!).
3. Translate 8,000+ text resources to American English (from British English).

Items 1 and 2 are the bulk of the work to be done. We also feel it's a appropriate to include American English to make American's feel comfortable with subtle differences in English - like colour vs color, aluminium vs aluminum, etc.

The multilingual features can be used at all times. Sometimes, carers may be from foreign countries with poor English. Imagine a nanny in New York, from Indonesia.

 

FUNDING TARGET: $10,000


Stretch Goals

With each additional $3,000 we can translate the service into other languages. Based on global popularity, these are: Spanish (included), French, Russian, Chinese, Arabic, German, Indonesian, Japanese, Hindi, etc.

* Translate 8,000+ text reources to other languages. This will done with a combination of machine translations but needs to be proof read by real people to ensure correctness.

 

WE NEED YOUR HELP !!

If you are a parent, an education professional or anyone interested in the potential of every young person, then you should pledge what you can!
story_txt:
Critical Years is an education platform that helps parents and early childhood professionals with the brain development of children.BackgroundThe first 5 years of brain development are the most critical in every persons life. Research shows that if you get the early years right, people go on to be positive contributors in society. Get it wrong and people will have learning problems in the future.The first 5 years are more important than K-12 and University combined, yet early education is one of the most neglected, over regulated and misunderstood fields in most countries throughout the world. Worse still, if you're a new parent, you're expected to know everything about child development when your first child is born.Did you know that something simple and innocent like encouraging a child to walk too soon can have a long term consequence on their development? Is there a problem with a child who talks late? That child may go on to be a great speaker. Every child learns differently. What matters is receiving a rich set of experiences that help encourage brain development.Yes, you could read a thousand books on child development. However, do these books address the unique requirements of your child at the right time? And who has the time to read, interpret and decide what is appropriate?As parents, we all need to accept that most of us have no idea what we're doing.... until now.What is Critical Years?Critical Years is an expert system and monitoring tool. It helps develop and capture the uniqueness of every child.As you might imagine, you can't put a 6 month old baby in front of a computer and expect them to do a multiple choice exam. story:
A little while ago we all stumbled upon this amazing opportunity to work as puppeteers in "The Fantastic Mr. Fox" puppet show that was held at artspace in Shreveport, Louisiana. This experience helped open our eyes to a whole new world of opportunity. We loved being able to bring the puppets in the show to life and to help create the world people were able to see. Before Fantastic Mr. Fox came to Artspace, none of us knew what to do with our talents and where to go to apply them to something we loved. This show helped us develop an undeniable love for puppetry and a desire to continue in our growth as puppeteers.

We are very excited to share with you that each of us have put a great deal of energy and hard work into qualifying to attend The Eugene O'Niell National Puppetry Conference in Waterford, Connecticut. We have an opportunity to attend this important and educational event that would help us grow not only as puppeteers but as artist as well. This conference is one of, if not the most, prestiges puppetry conferences in the world. This Conference creates outrageous works of theater that defy imagination and confound expectations over the course of just eight days. All of us will be able to work and collaborate with nationally and internationally renowned puppeteers. These puppeteers will be training us through performance styles and techniques in rehearsals, workshops, and master classes. Past participants of this conference have went on to work for such puppetry venues as Sesame Street, Crank Yankers, Bear in the Big Blue House, Between the Lions, Wakka Wakka Productions, The Jim Henson Foundation, and numerous theaters all over the United States.

In order for us to attend this puppetry conference, we have to raise $4300 to fund the trip. The money is necessary to cover transportation, accommodations, and admission into the conference for all three of us. We're contacting the community to request financial assistance for us to make the trip. Any amount you donate will be greatly appreciated and go directly to this important, educational, and life- changing experience.

Thank you so much for your help. Noah Scruggs, Elizabeth Jackson, Cazes Verbois and Sara Elsberg

story:
OVERVIEW

My name is Jillian, I am at 22 year old nurse from Ontario, Canada and on May 30th I will be travelling to Nairobi, Kenya to volunteer at an orphanage for a month.  I have done a lot of research into my trip and have developed a project called We Are One (W.O.A) who's main focus is to integrate education into orphanages. I found out that orphans are the last to receive education, and usually are not granted the ability to go to to school so my goal is to integrate one to two hours of education daily into the orphanage I am placed at. Self esteem building and language skills (reading, writing spelling) will be my biggest focuses as well as world issues and mathematics. We are so fortunate in North America and often take education for granted. Unfortunatley supplies and resources are scarce and any initiatives I want to take are all my own money. I need school supplies, teaching supplies, snacks and lesson plans all of which will cost money, as well my volunteer trip is already costing 3000$. I hope that you guys appreciate my cause and this is a way you can give to a cause without actually having to travel there.

What We Need & What You Get

To break it down for you here are my costs:

My cost are based on my travel expense and the supplies I hope to purchase for my We Are One project...these are supplies that are desperatley needed

My Flight from Canada to Kenya-$1600

My Visa- $100

Vaccinations-$400

Medical Insurance-$150

I will be staying with a Kenyan family to experience their way of life

Living Expenses-$700...If any of you would like proof of this you can contact my volunteer co-ordinator I would be happy to provide you with her info, also visit volunteerhq.org to see what I will be doing!

I need to purchase some clothing, shoes, many school supplies (including pens, paper, pencils, craft work, art supplies, books. sports equipment), teaching supplies such as white boards, chalk etc. My hope is to purchase most of these items in Nairobi as this money will actually go back into the Kenyan economy to help.

My estimate for all of this is approximately $1500-$2000 as these orphanages have NOTHING towards supplies for teaching!

- I really hope to implement self confidence in these kids. Losing their parents and families to violence and HIV/AIDS will have left a serious scar to these children, and having a mental health background in nursing I hope to put my counselling and coping skills to use. I also want to help with language skills including, reading, writing and spelling English is one of the national languages in Kenya (along with Swahili) however schools and orphanages are so short staffed and have such a lack of resources that children often never learn to read or write. Finally I want to get their input as to what they would like to learn and get them excited about learning and teaching each other. 

The Impact

You contributions will make more difference than you can imaginel Picture if it was you abandoned and left as orphan, wouldn't you want to still be treated with respect and get the same education as other children? I know you may think it's too far to even have to care, but take a look at where you live what if it happened there? You need to know that every dollar and intention to help will be used to its greatest ability. I will make sure I do my best to show you all how your donations have helped. I have worked hard to save a good chunk for this trip, however I need the help getting the rest. I am not just going to follow a program and say I went and made a difference, I have put a lot of work and thought into this project and I hope you can see the change we can make. Ghandi once said "You must be the change you want to see in the world". I think I will leave it at that, and thank you for taking the time to view my cause!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate just spread the word about W.A.O to your friends your family, anyone who is looking to help. I know spreading the word will create awareness and even if I do not reach my goal if I can get even a few people informed about these children I have made a differencel I will do the best I can with what I have, but know that your 50 cents, your five or your twenty dollars can make a kid feel special, even for a dayl Thank you!

story:
LATEST NEWS 1: The Oxford Burma Alliance has just donated $1,200! Thanks guys! That's about 6 months worth of office space!

LATEST NEWS 2: We're really happy to announce the support of the Oxford Burma Alliance! They're a great organisation raising awareness about Burma issues and creating long-lasting advocacy in the UK. Read about their work here!

LATEST NEWS 3: We've just been featured in Burma's independent media magazine, The Irrawaddy! Read the article here!

Our story

Escaping Burma

Burma is home to one of the world’s longest-ruling military dictatorships and the world’s longest-running civil war. Education is limited, the media is controlled and many young people – refugees, migrants, students – flee through the jungles to Thailand’s border towns, seeking a better life.

Their chances are poor. Working and sleeping in factories, farms and shops, or living in the numerous refugee camps, they have little chance to improve themselves and they quickly lose their confidence and hopes.

The Young Generation’s Note...

In mid-2011 a small group of us young migrants on the Thai-Burma border wanted to change things for the better. So we began making a monthly magazine, full of content created by and for migrants and refugees – news, stories, articles, poems, photography, cartoons and more.

  • every month we distribute the magazine to refugee camps, factories and migrant schools
  • we bring news to divided families
  • we share inspiring stories and experiences
  • we publish the writing of refugees and migrants, giving them a voice
  • and we try to strengthen the fractured Burmese community

You can read the magazine's March 2012 issue here (15mb).

We need your help!

Please help us to improve the futures of young Burmese migrants and their communities! We need your support to help our project become financially sustainable!

Where your money goes / why every dollar matters:

  • $5 = 7 copies of the magazine. That means we can reach 7 more migrant schools, orphanages and refugee camps.
    Also we'd meet requests from paying advertisers for a larger printing run.
  • $150 = office space for 1 month, where the team can work and provide training in a safe, secure environment.
  • $1,600 dollars = a photocopier, allowing self-printing and our own photocopy service. This means an independent, guaranteed source of income.

Our funding goal:

  • Printing 500 copies a month for refugees and migrants for 1 year: $4,200
  • Photocopier: $1,600
  • Year's office space: $2,000
  • Taxes and fees: $1,000

Total = $8,800

 

The impact

Every day we see the magazine attracting more and more readers and support. It’s building confidence and raising the aspirations of the Burmese migrants and refugees in Mae Sot.

But the impact reaches further. Empowering young migrants means that when they return they can help build a strong national media, encourage better systems of government and help their country to develop.

Free media training:

With this in mind we've recently started offering free media training for migrants and refugees in creative writing, photography, video-production and more. Students go on to train other migrants and refugees, as well as those back in Burma.

  • we aim to create a sustainable future of creative and empowered young people
  • we train people to think analytically
  • we help people understand the power of the media

 

Other ways you can help:

  1. Please shout about our campaign! Use the share buttons here to share this page via Facebook or Twitter!
  2. Tell your friends, family and local media about The Young Generation’s Note – spread the word offline and on!
  3. Ask us for a story – we’d love to tell you more about what we are doing. Anything to help promote the project!

 

By helping the Young Generation’s Note you will be helping improve the prospects of young Burmese migrants and refugees, their communities and the future of Burma as a whole!

Our deepest thanks to you all,

Sat Kyar and The Young Generation’s Note team

story:
And just who am I? My name is Gustavo and I post as @predictionmonk on Twitter.

Around 2014, I embarked on a project to build a narrow-AI (Artificial Intelligence) named Elixir.

The goal? To predict the Nasdaq-100, perhaps the most popular technology-heavy index in global finance.

Today, this goal is no longer a dream. For over 1 year, I have posted Elixir's performance on a freemium model: to dozens of my own clients in my Patreon page, and to about 40K followers on my Twitter page - see it below:

https://twitter.com/predictionmonk

 

And just how reliable is Elixir? Below is commentary by one of our earliest followers:

https://twitter.com/MoMoBagholder/status/115673...

And yet, Elixir has not applied her full potential - she can do same-day forecasts.

 

Currently, Elixir performs evening-runs for next-day forecasts. These process data up to market close (4pm ET) on a given day - and produces a fairly reliable forecast for the next day.

But morning-runs are more current. They absorb data up to market open (0930am ET), including overnight action - to deliver a *same-day* forecast.

 

What is the difference in performance?

Well, evening-runs have probabilities of success in the mid-50s to mid-70s (typically).

Morning-runs, on the other hand, have probabilities regularly in the mid-60s to upper-80s (erring on the conservative side).

 

Intrigued? I discuss more details in the FAQs below:

story:
WE Rock Australia is the most talked about 4wd event in Australia right now!

 

The event has recently been featured in:

  1. DirtComp Magazine Print media
  2. DirtComp Magazine Online
  3. 4WD Nation Magazine
  4. All over the Internet
  5. Facebook
  6. CRAWL magazine USA


    We believe in creating memorable events for both drivers and spectators. With 5 rounds in the next 12 months, WE Rock Australia will be a traveling road show of the nations best buggies.



    These insane single seat and small buggies will be competing on massive two story granite boulders in NSW, man-made courses in sunny SE Qld and a whole lot of natural terrain in between.



    Take a look at the recent event in the USA where spectators are treated like royalty, competitors are there to put on a show and most of all, the sponsors are getting exposure...

     



    World Extreme Rock Crawling is an international series of events to test the toughest crawling buggies and vehicles on insane courses.



    What We Need & What You Get

    W.E.Rock Australia is a four round series that is high on action for both competitors and spectators alike. After a seven year hiatus in Australia, the series returns under new management.

    With major corporate sponsors already involved, we are looking to boost our spectator comfort at the events by outlaying more funds on amenities and sideshow entertainment.

    Watch the video we have included to see the style of driving the teams will undertake.



    The Impact

    The importance of your donation will be towards a greater spectator experience. While we have corporate backing to fund things like event insurance and logistics, the spectators are often an overlooked part of a race event. 



    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

    • As officials at an event, you'll get free camping and see the action, all you have to do it show up and help us with small tasks.
    • Please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word of this event and this crowd funding campaign to benefit spectators.

    Thanks for the help and thank you for taking the time to either commit to a donation, sharing the campaign on your social media pages or turning up to the event to help out.

Take a look at the recent event in the USA where spectators are treated like royalty, competitors are there to put on a show and most of all, the sponsors are getting exposure...
 
World Extreme Rock Crawling is an international series of events to test the toughest crawling buggies and vehicles on insane courses.  What We Need & What You Get 
W.E.Rock Australia is a four round series that is high on action for 
both competitors and spectators alike. After a seven year hiatus in 
Australia, the series returns under new management.
With major 
corporate sponsors already involved, we are looking to boost our 
spectator comfort at the events by outlaying more funds on amenities 
and sideshow entertainment.
Watch the video we have included to see the style of driving the teams will undertake.


  The Impact The importance of your donation will be towards a greater spectator experience. While we have corporate backing to fund things like event insurance and logistics, the spectators are often an overlooked part of a race event. 


  Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:
As officials at an event, you'll get free camping and see the action, all you have to do it show up and help us with small tasks.


Please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word of this event and this crowd funding campaign to benefit spectators.
 
 Thanks for the help and thank you for taking the time to either commit to a donation, sharing the campaign on your social media pages or turning up to the event to help out.
